subject: Life Science
title: Photosynthesis
whatIsIt: Photosynthesis is the process plants use to convert sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into glucose (sugar) and oxygen. It is the foundation of almost all life on Earth because it produces the food and oxygen that animals need.
howItWorks: Photosynthesis happens in two main stages inside chloroplasts. In the light-dependent reactions, chlorophyll in the thylakoid membranes captures light energy. This energy splits water molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct and producing ATP and NADPH. In the Calvin cycle (light-independent reactions), these energy carriers are used to fix carbon dioxide from the air into organic molecules, eventually building glucose. The overall equation is: 6 CO₂ + 6 H₂O + light → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6 O₂.
realWorldExample: When you see a green lawn or a forest, every green part is busy doing photosynthesis. The oxygen you breathe comes mostly from ocean phytoplankton and land plants doing this process.

keyTerms.definition: The green pigment in chloroplasts that captures light energy.
The organelle where photosynthesis takes place in plant cells.
A simple sugar (C₆H₁₂O₆) that is the main product of photosynthesis.
Small openings on leaves that let CO₂ in and O₂ out.
Light-independent reactions that build glucose from CO₂ using ATP and NADPH.

nsbTraps: Students often confuse the reactants and products: CO₂ and water go IN; glucose and oxygen come OUT.
Photosynthesis happens in chloroplasts, not mitochondria (that's cellular respiration).
didYouKnow: A single leaf can have about 500,000 chloroplasts per square millimeter.
The oxygen in every other breath you take likely came from the ocean.

subject: Life Science
title: Cell Structure & Organelles
whatIsIt: Cells are the basic units of life. Plant and animal cells share many organelles, but plant cells have a cell wall and chloroplasts that animal cells do not.
howItWorks: The nucleus holds DNA and controls the cell. Mitochondria make ATP (energy). Ribosomes build proteins. The endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus process and ship proteins. Vacuoles store materials; in plants the central vacuole helps maintain shape. Lysosomes break down waste. The cell membrane controls what enters and leaves.
realWorldExample: Your muscles have lots of mitochondria because they need lots of energy. Plant leaf cells are packed with chloroplasts for photosynthesis.

keyTerms.definition: Membrane-bound organelle that contains DNA and controls cell activities.
Organelle where cellular respiration produces ATP.
Site of protein synthesis; can be free or attached to ER.
Phospholipid bilayer that controls what enters and exits the cell.
Organelle in plant cells where photosynthesis occurs.

nsbTraps: Plant cells have both a cell wall and a cell membrane; animal cells only have a cell membrane.
Ribosomes are in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes; the nucleus is only in eukaryotes.
didYouKnow: Mitochondria have their own DNA and may have evolved from free-living bacteria.

subject: Life Science
title: Cell Processes
whatIsIt: Cells constantly move materials in and out. Osmosis, diffusion, and active transport are three key ways substances cross the cell membrane without the cell having to eat or drink in the way we do.
howItWorks: Diffusion is the movement of particles from an area of higher concentration to lower concentration until equilibrium is reached; it does not require energy. Osmosis is diffusion of water across a membrane. Active transport moves substances against the concentration gradient (from low to high) and requires energy (ATP) and often protein pumps.
realWorldExample: When you add salt to a cucumber slice, water leaves the cells by osmosis and the slice shrinks. Roots take in minerals by active transport so they can concentrate nutrients from dilute soil water.

keyTerms.definition: Movement of particles from high to low concentration without energy.
Diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane.
Movement of substances against the concentration gradient using ATP.
Difference in concentration between two areas; diffusion goes down the gradient.
A membrane that allows some substances through but not others.

nsbTraps: Osmosis is only about water; diffusion can be any particle. Don't say 'osmosis of salt'—salt moves by diffusion.
Active transport requires energy; diffusion and osmosis do not.
didYouKnow: Your kidneys use osmosis and active transport to filter blood and reabsorb useful molecules.
Plant roots use active transport to pull in nitrate and other ions from soil.

subject: Life Science
title: Cell Division
whatIsIt: Cells divide to grow, repair tissues, and make reproductive cells. Mitosis produces two identical body cells; meiosis produces four gametes with half the chromosomes.
howItWorks: The cell cycle has interphase (growth and DNA replication), then mitosis: prophase, metaphase, anaphase, telophase, and cytokinesis (splitting the cytoplasm). Mitosis keeps the same number of chromosomes (e.g., 46 in humans). Meiosis has two divisions: the first halves the chromosome number; the second separates sister chromatids, producing four haploid cells.
realWorldExample: When you scrape your knee, mitosis in skin cells fills in the wound. Sperm and egg are produced by meiosis so that when they fuse, the baby has the correct number of chromosomes.

keyTerms.definition: Division that produces two genetically identical daughter cells; used for growth and repair.
Division that produces four gametes with half the chromosomes; used for reproduction.
Condensed DNA and protein; carries genes.
Division of the cytoplasm after mitosis or meiosis.
Having one set of chromosomes (n); gametes are haploid.
Having two sets of chromosomes (2n); body cells are diploid.

nsbTraps: Mitosis = identical copies (same chromosome number). Meiosis = gametes (half the chromosomes).
Interphase is when DNA replicates; mitosis doesn't duplicate DNA, it separates already-duplicated chromosomes.
didYouKnow: Cancer is often a failure of the cell cycle—cells divide when they shouldn't.
Down syndrome results from an extra copy of chromosome 21, a meiosis error.

subject: Life Science
title: Cellular Respiration
whatIsIt: Cellular respiration is how cells release energy from glucose (and other fuels) to make ATP. It happens in the mitochondria and uses oxygen (aerobic) or, in some cases, proceeds without oxygen (anaerobic).
howItWorks: Glycolysis in the cytoplasm breaks one glucose into two pyruvate molecules and makes a little ATP. In aerobic respiration, pyruvate enters the mitochondria: the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain use oxygen to make many more ATP. The overall equation is: C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6 O₂ → 6 CO₂ + 6 H₂O + ATP. Anaerobic respiration (e.g., fermentation) does not use oxygen and produces less ATP; in muscles it makes lactate; in yeast it makes ethanol and CO₂.
realWorldExample: When you run, your muscles need lots of ATP; they do aerobic respiration. If you sprint and run out of breath, they switch to anaerobic and you feel the burn from lactate.

keyTerms.definition: Adenosine triphosphate; the main energy currency of the cell.
First stage of respiration; breaks glucose into pyruvate in the cytoplasm.
Using oxygen; aerobic respiration produces much more ATP than anaerobic.
Without oxygen; fermentation is a type of anaerobic respiration.
Organelle where the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain occur.

nsbTraps: Respiration happens in mitochondria (and cytoplasm for glycolysis); photosynthesis happens in chloroplasts. Don't swap them.
We breathe to get oxygen for cellular respiration; we exhale CO₂ produced by respiration.
didYouKnow: Photosynthesis and respiration are almost opposite reactions: plants do both.
Some bacteria do anaerobic respiration and don't need oxygen at all.

subject: Life Science
title: DNA & RNA
whatIsIt: DNA stores genetic information; RNA helps use that information to build proteins. DNA is double-stranded and stays in the nucleus; RNA is single-stranded and can leave the nucleus.
howItWorks: DNA is made of nucleotides (sugar, phosphate, and a base: A, T, G, C). Replication copies DNA before cell division. In transcription, DNA is copied into mRNA in the nucleus. In translation, mRNA is read by ribosomes to build proteins using tRNA and amino acids. The sequence of bases in DNA (genes) codes for the sequence of amino acids in proteins.
realWorldExample: When you grow, your cells replicate DNA so each new cell has a full set of instructions. When you digest food, enzymes (which are proteins) are made by reading genes through transcription and translation.

keyTerms.definition: Process of copying DNA before cell division.
Copying DNA into mRNA in the nucleus.
Reading mRNA on ribosomes to build proteins.
A segment of DNA that codes for a protein or functional RNA.
Messenger RNA; carries the code from DNA to the ribosome.
In DNA, A with T and G with C; in RNA, A with U and G with C.

nsbTraps: DNA has T (thymine); RNA has U (uracil). Don't say 'DNA has uracil.'
Transcription makes RNA from DNA; translation makes protein from RNA. Order matters.
didYouKnow: If you stretched out all the DNA in one cell, it would be about 2 meters long.
The same genetic code is used by almost all living things—evidence for common ancestry.

subject: Life Science
title: Genetics & Heredity
whatIsIt: Genetics is the study of how traits are passed from parents to offspring. Genes come in versions called alleles; dominant alleles can mask recessive ones.
howItWorks: Offspring get one allele from each parent. In Mendelian genetics, dominant (capital letter) masks recessive (lowercase). A Punnett square shows possible offspring genotypes. Homozygous means two same alleles (AA or aa); heterozygous means two different (Aa). Phenotype is what you see; genotype is the genetic makeup.
realWorldExample: If both parents are heterozygous for brown eyes (Bb), there's a 1 in 4 chance of a blue-eyed (bb) child. Pea plants helped Mendel discover these rules.

keyTerms.definition: One version of a gene; e.g., allele for brown eyes vs. blue eyes.
An allele that shows its trait even when only one copy is present.
An allele that only shows when two copies are present.
A diagram used to predict the genotypes of offspring.
The genetic makeup (e.g., AA, Aa, aa).
The observable trait (e.g., brown eyes, tall).

nsbTraps: Dominant does not mean 'most common'—recessive traits can be common in a population.
Two heterozygous parents can have homozygous recessive offspring (25% chance for one gene).
didYouKnow: Mendel worked with pea plants in the 1800s; his work was rediscovered decades later.
Many traits are controlled by multiple genes, not just one.

subject: Life Science
title: Mutations & Genetic Variation
whatIsIt: A mutation is a change in the DNA sequence. Mutations can be harmful, helpful, or have no effect. They are the raw material for evolution.
howItWorks: Mutations can happen from copying errors during replication, UV light, chemicals, or other factors. Point mutations change one or a few bases; frameshift mutations (insertion or deletion) shift how the code is read. Some mutations affect a single gene; others change chromosome number or structure. Only mutations in gametes (egg or sperm) are passed to offspring.
realWorldExample: Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the hemoglobin gene. Some people have a mutation that makes them unable to taste bitter compounds.

keyTerms.definition: A change in the DNA sequence.
Change in a single nucleotide (base).
Insertion or deletion that shifts how codons are read; often serious.
Differences in DNA among individuals in a population.
Something that causes mutations (e.g., UV radiation, some chemicals).

nsbTraps: Not all mutations cause disease—many have no effect or are beneficial.
Only mutations in reproductive cells are inherited; body cell mutations are not passed on.
didYouKnow: Mutations created the variety of dog breeds from a common ancestor.
Some mutations can be repaired by the cell's own enzymes.

subject: Life Science
title: Evolution & Natural Selection
whatIsIt: Evolution is the change in heritable traits in a population over time. Natural selection is the main mechanism: organisms with traits better suited to the environment tend to survive and reproduce more.
howItWorks: There is variation in populations (from mutations and sexual reproduction). Some individuals are better adapted; they survive and pass their genes to the next generation. Over many generations, the population's traits shift. Adaptation is a trait that improves survival or reproduction. Speciation can occur when populations become isolated and diverge enough to become different species.
realWorldExample: Peppered moths in England became darker when pollution darkened tree bark—birds ate the light ones. Antibiotic-resistant bacteria evolve because the ones that survive treatment reproduce.

keyTerms.definition: Process by which better-adapted individuals survive and reproduce more.
A trait that helps an organism survive and reproduce in its environment.
A group of organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
Formation of a new species, often after geographic or reproductive isolation.
In evolution, how well an organism survives and reproduces in its environment.

nsbTraps: Individuals don't evolve—populations do. A single organism doesn't 'adapt' in the evolutionary sense during its life.
Natural selection doesn't aim for 'perfection'—it favors what works in the current environment.
didYouKnow: Darwin and Wallace both proposed natural selection; Darwin's On the Origin of Species is famous.
Evolution is supported by fossils, comparative anatomy, DNA, and observed changes in populations.

subject: Life Science
title: Classification of Life
whatIsIt: Scientists classify living things into a hierarchy: domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species. Binomial nomenclature gives each species a two-part Latin name (genus + species).
howItWorks: The three domains are Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya. Eukarya includes kingdoms such as Protista, Fungi, Plantae, and Animalia. Closer groups share more recent common ancestors. Scientific names are italicized; the genus is capitalized (e.g., Homo sapiens).
realWorldExample: Lions (Panthera leo) and tigers (Panthera tigris) share the same genus, so they're closely related. You're Homo sapiens—genus Homo, species sapiens.

keyTerms.definition: The science of naming and classifying organisms.
Two-part scientific name: genus and species (e.g., Felis catus).
The broadest category; Bacteria, Archaea, Eukarya.
Major group within a domain (e.g., Animalia, Plantae).
Most specific level; organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.

nsbTraps: Kingdom and domain are not the same—there are multiple kingdoms within Eukarya.
Common names vary by language; scientific names are the same worldwide.
didYouKnow: Linnaeus developed the system we still use today in the 1700s.
DNA evidence has changed how we group some organisms (e.g., reclassifying some protists).

subject: Life Science
title: Bacteria & Viruses
whatIsIt: Bacteria are single-celled prokaryotes (no nucleus); they live everywhere and many are harmless or helpful. Viruses are not cells—they're particles that need a host to reproduce and can cause disease.
howItWorks: Bacteria have a cell wall, cell membrane, cytoplasm, and DNA in a nucleoid (no nuclear envelope). They reproduce by binary fission. Viruses have genetic material (DNA or RNA) in a protein coat; they attach to host cells, inject their genes, and hijack the cell to make more viruses. Antibiotics kill bacteria but don't work on viruses.
realWorldExample: Yogurt and cheese are made by bacteria. The flu and COVID-19 are caused by viruses. Your gut has trillions of bacteria that help digestion.

keyTerms.definition: Organism whose cells lack a nucleus; bacteria and archaea.
Asexual reproduction in bacteria; one cell splits into two.
Non-living particle that needs a host cell to replicate.
Organism or cell that a virus or parasite uses to reproduce.
Medicine that kills or stops bacteria; not effective against viruses.

nsbTraps: Viruses are not alive—they don't grow, eat, or reproduce on their own. Bacteria are alive.
Not all bacteria are bad; many are essential. Not all viruses cause disease in humans.
didYouKnow: There are more bacterial cells in your body than human cells.
Some viruses insert their DNA into the host's genome and stay for a long time.

subject: Life Science
title: Fungi & Protists
whatIsIt: Fungi are eukaryotes that absorb nutrients from their environment (decomposers, parasites, or mutualists); they include mushrooms, yeast, and mold. Protists are a diverse group of mostly single-celled eukaryotes that don't fit neatly into plants, animals, or fungi.
howItWorks: Fungi have cell walls (often of chitin), grow as hyphae that form mycelium, and reproduce with spores. Yeast is single-celled and does fermentation. Protists include algae (plant-like), amoebas (animal-like), and slime molds; some cause disease (e.g., malaria from Plasmodium).
realWorldExample: Bread rises because yeast ferments and releases CO₂. Pond scum and seaweed are protists. Athlete's foot is caused by a fungus.

keyTerms.definition: Eukaryote that absorbs nutrients; has cell walls of chitin.
Thread-like filament that makes up the body of many fungi.
Reproductive cell that can develop into a new organism without fertilization.
Diverse eukaryotes that are not plants, animals, or fungi.
Organism that breaks down dead matter and returns nutrients to the ecosystem.

nsbTraps: Fungi are not plants—they don't do photosynthesis and have chitin in their cell walls.
Protist is a catch-all group; some protists are more closely related to plants or animals than to other protists.
didYouKnow: The largest organism on Earth may be a fungus—a honey mushroom in Oregon spanning miles.
Plasmodium, which causes malaria, is a protist spread by mosquitoes.

subject: Life Science
title: Plant Biology
whatIsIt: Plants have roots, stems, and leaves; vascular tissue (xylem and phloem) moves water and sugars. They make their own food by photosynthesis and reproduce with spores or seeds.
howItWorks: Roots absorb water and minerals and anchor the plant. Xylem carries water and minerals upward; phloem carries sugars (from photosynthesis) where they're needed. Leaves have stomata for gas exchange. Plants reproduce sexually (flowers, pollination, seeds) or asexually (runners, cuttings). Gymnosperms have naked seeds (e.g., conifers); angiosperms have flowers and enclosed seeds.
realWorldExample: When you water a plant, roots take in water and xylem moves it to the leaves. Bees pollinate flowers so seeds can form. Maple syrup comes from phloem sap.

keyTerms.definition: Vascular tissue that carries water and minerals from roots upward.
Vascular tissue that carries sugars and other nutrients throughout the plant.
Openings in leaves (and stems) for gas exchange; allow CO₂ in and O₂ out.
Transfer of pollen to the female part of a flower for fertilization.
Flowering plant; seeds enclosed in fruit.
Seed plant with naked seeds (e.g., conifers); no flowers.

nsbTraps: Xylem goes up (water and minerals); phloem can go up or down (sugars to where they're needed).
Plants don't 'breathe' like us—they take in CO₂ and release O₂ through stomata for photosynthesis.
didYouKnow: Some of the oldest living organisms are plants—e.g., bristlecone pines over 5,000 years old.
Venus flytraps and pitcher plants get extra nutrients by digesting insects.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Circulatory System
whatIsIt: The circulatory system moves blood around the body, delivering oxygen and nutrients and carrying away waste and CO₂. The heart pumps blood through arteries, capillaries, and veins.
howItWorks: The heart has four chambers: two atria (receive blood) and two ventricles (pump blood). Blood flows: body → veins → right atrium → right ventricle → lungs (pick up O₂, drop CO₂) → left atrium → left ventricle → arteries → body. Red blood cells carry oxygen using hemoglobin; plasma carries nutrients, hormones, and waste. Arteries carry blood away from the heart; veins carry it back.
realWorldExample: When you run, your heart beats faster to deliver more oxygen to your muscles. A cut bleeds because capillaries are damaged.

keyTerms.definition: Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart; usually oxygen-rich (except pulmonary artery).
Blood vessel that carries blood toward the heart; usually oxygen-poor (except pulmonary vein).
Tiny vessel where exchange of gases and nutrients with tissues occurs.
Protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.
Upper chamber of the heart that receives blood.
Lower chamber that pumps blood out of the heart.

nsbTraps: Arteries don't always carry oxygenated blood—the pulmonary artery carries blood to the lungs to get oxygen.
Blood in veins is not always blue; it's dark red. Veins look blue through skin due to how light is absorbed.
didYouKnow: Your heart beats about 100,000 times per day.
Earthworms have a closed circulatory system; insects have an open one with hemolymph.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Respiratory System
whatIsIt: The respiratory system brings oxygen into the body and removes carbon dioxide. In humans, air enters through the nose or mouth, passes through the trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles, and reaches the alveoli where gas exchange happens.
howItWorks: When you inhale, the diaphragm and rib muscles contract, expanding the chest so air flows in. In the alveoli (tiny air sacs), oxygen diffuses into the blood and CO₂ diffuses out. When you exhale, the diaphragm relaxes and air is pushed out. Breathing is controlled by the brain in response to CO₂ levels in the blood.
realWorldExample: When you hold your breath, CO₂ builds up and eventually your brain forces you to breathe. At high altitude there's less oxygen, so you breathe faster.

keyTerms.definition: Windpipe; carries air from throat to bronchi.
Tiny air sac in the lung where gas exchange with blood occurs.
Muscle below the lungs that contracts to pull air in and relaxes to push air out.
One of the two main tubes that branch from the trachea into the lungs.
Diffusion of O₂ into blood and CO₂ out of blood in the alveoli.

nsbTraps: We breathe to get oxygen for cellular respiration, but the trigger to breathe is usually rising CO₂, not low oxygen.
Air goes to alveoli; blood goes to alveoli in capillaries—they're the site of exchange, not the mouth.
didYouKnow: You have about 300 million alveoli in your lungs—huge surface area for gas exchange.
Fish use gills for gas exchange; water flows over gill filaments where O₂ diffuses in.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Digestive System
whatIsIt: The digestive system breaks down food into nutrients the body can absorb and use. It includes the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and accessory organs like the liver and pancreas.
howItWorks: Mechanical digestion (chewing, stomach churning) and chemical digestion (enzymes and acid) break food into small molecules. In the small intestine, nutrients are absorbed into the blood. The large intestine absorbs water and forms feces. The liver makes bile (stored in gallbladder) to help digest fats; the pancreas releases enzymes and bicarbonate.
realWorldExample: When you eat a sandwich, amylase in saliva starts breaking down starch. Protein is digested in the stomach and small intestine. Fiber isn't digested but helps move material through the large intestine.

keyTerms.definition: Protein that speeds up chemical reactions; digestive enzymes break down food molecules.
Where most digestion and absorption of nutrients occurs; has villi to increase surface area.
Finger-like projections in the small intestine that increase surface area for absorption.
Makes bile, processes nutrients, detoxifies; bile helps digest fats.
Wave-like muscle contractions that move food through the digestive tract.

nsbTraps: Absorption of nutrients happens mainly in the small intestine, not the stomach.
The stomach absorbs very little—mostly alcohol and some water. Don't say 'stomach absorbs nutrients.'
didYouKnow: The small intestine is about 6 meters long; its villi give it the surface area of a tennis court.
Stomach acid is strong enough to kill many bacteria in food.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Nervous System & Brain
whatIsIt: The nervous system receives information from the environment and body, processes it, and coordinates responses. The brain and spinal cord make up the central nervous system (CNS); nerves make up the peripheral nervous system (PNS).
howItWorks: Neurons (nerve cells) carry electrical signals. Sensory neurons bring information from sense organs to the CNS; motor neurons carry commands from the CNS to muscles and glands. At synapses, chemicals (neurotransmitters) pass the signal to the next cell. The brain has regions for different functions: cerebrum (thinking, voluntary movement), cerebellum (balance, coordination), brainstem (breathing, heart rate).
realWorldExample: When you touch something hot, sensory neurons send 'hot!' to your spinal cord and brain; motor neurons tell your hand to pull away in a reflex. Learning and memory involve changes at synapses.

keyTerms.definition: Nerve cell that carries electrical impulses.
Junction where a neuron passes a signal to another cell using neurotransmitters.
Brain and spinal cord.
Nerves that connect the CNS to the rest of the body.
Rapid, automatic response that can involve the spinal cord without the brain.
Largest part of the brain; involved in thinking, memory, and voluntary movement.

nsbTraps: Reflexes can happen without the brain (spinal reflex)—so 'reflex' doesn't always mean the brain decided.
Neurons don't touch—there's a gap (synapse) where neurotransmitters cross.
didYouKnow: The human brain has about 86 billion neurons.
The left side of the brain often controls the right side of the body, and vice versa.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Endocrine System
whatIsIt: The endocrine system uses hormones—chemical signals released into the blood—to regulate growth, metabolism, mood, and many other processes. Glands make and release hormones; target cells have receptors that respond.
howItWorks: The pituitary gland (in the brain) is often called the 'master gland' because it controls other glands. The thyroid regulates metabolism; the adrenal glands help with stress and blood pressure; the pancreas releases insulin and glucagon to control blood sugar. Hormones work slowly and their effects can last a long time. Negative feedback keeps hormone levels in balance.
realWorldExample: When blood sugar rises after a meal, the pancreas releases insulin so cells take up glucose. Growth hormone from the pituitary helps you grow during puberty.

keyTerms.definition: Chemical messenger released by glands into the blood; affects target cells.
Organ or group of cells that makes and releases hormones or other substances.
Small gland in the brain that controls many other endocrine glands.
Hormone from the pancreas that lowers blood sugar by helping cells take in glucose.
When a response reduces the stimulus (e.g., insulin lowers sugar; when sugar is low, less insulin is released).

nsbTraps: Hormones travel in blood; neurotransmitters work across synapses. Don't confuse the two.
The pancreas is both an exocrine gland (digestive enzymes) and endocrine (insulin, glucagon).
didYouKnow: Diabetes occurs when the body doesn't make enough insulin or doesn't respond to it.
The adrenal gland releases adrenaline (epinephrine) in 'fight or flight' situations.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Immune System
whatIsIt: The immune system defends the body against pathogens (bacteria, viruses, and other invaders). It has nonspecific defenses (barriers, inflammation) and specific defenses (antibodies and immune cells that recognize particular pathogens).
howItWorks: Skin and mucous membranes are first-line barriers. If a pathogen gets in, white blood cells attack: some engulf invaders (phagocytes), others make antibodies that bind to specific antigens. Vaccines train the immune system to recognize a pathogen without getting sick. Memory cells 'remember' past infections for a faster response next time. Allergies are an overreaction to harmless substances.
realWorldExample: When you get a cut, the area may swell and turn red—that's inflammation bringing immune cells to fight germs. After recovering from chickenpox, you usually don't get it again because of immune memory.

keyTerms.definition: Disease-causing organism or virus.
Protein made by immune cells that binds to a specific antigen and helps destroy the pathogen.
Molecule on a pathogen (or other substance) that the immune system recognizes.
Preparation that trains the immune system to recognize a pathogen without causing disease.
Cell that fights infection; includes phagocytes and lymphocytes.

nsbTraps: Antibiotics kill bacteria, not viruses. Antibodies are made by your body; antibiotics are medicines.
Vaccines don't give you the disease—they use weakened or dead pathogens or pieces of them to trigger immunity.
didYouKnow: You have more bacterial cells in your body than human cells, but most don't make you sick.
Some white blood cells can 'remember' a pathogen for decades.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Skeletal & Muscular Systems
whatIsIt: The skeleton provides support, protects organs, and (with muscles) allows movement. Bones store minerals and make blood cells. Muscles contract to pull on bones; they work in pairs (e.g., bicep and tricep) to move joints.
howItWorks: Bones are connected by ligaments; muscles are attached to bones by tendons. Skeletal muscle is voluntary and striated; smooth muscle (e.g., in the digestive tract) and cardiac muscle (heart) are involuntary. When a muscle contracts, it shortens and pulls the bone. Muscles need ATP from cellular respiration; they also need oxygen, which is why you breathe hard when you exercise.
realWorldExample: When you bend your arm, the bicep contracts and the tricep relaxes. To straighten your arm, the tricep contracts and the bicep relaxes. Broken bones can heal because bone cells make new matrix.

keyTerms.definition: Connective tissue that connects bone to bone at a joint.
Connective tissue that connects muscle to bone.
Muscle you can control (e.g., skeletal muscle).
Muscle you don't consciously control (e.g., heart, digestive tract).
Where two bones meet; can be movable (knee) or not (skull sutures).

nsbTraps: Muscles only pull; they don't push. So you need paired muscles for two-way movement.
Bones are living tissue—they have cells, blood vessels, and can repair themselves.
didYouKnow: You have more than 200 bones at birth; some fuse so adults have about 206.
The strongest muscle by weight is the masseter (jaw); the largest is the gluteus maximus.

subject: Life Science
title: Animal Systems: Reproductive System
whatIsIt: The reproductive system produces gametes (sperm and egg) and, in many animals, supports fertilization and development of offspring. In humans, male reproductive organs produce sperm; female organs produce eggs and support pregnancy.
howItWorks: Meiosis produces haploid gametes. In fertilization, sperm and egg fuse to form a zygote with the full set of chromosomes. The zygote divides by mitosis and develops into an embryo, then a fetus. Reproductive hormones (e.g., from the pituitary and gonads) control the development of gametes and secondary sex characteristics. Different organisms reproduce in different ways: internal or external fertilization; live birth or eggs.
realWorldExample: In humans, one egg is usually released per month from the ovaries. Sperm are produced continuously in the testes. When a sperm fertilizes an egg, development begins.

keyTerms.definition: Reproductive cell (sperm or egg) with half the normal chromosomes.
Fusion of sperm and egg to form a zygote.
Fertilized egg; first cell of a new individual.
Cell division that produces gametes with half the chromosome number.
Female organ that produces eggs (and hormones).
Male organ that produces sperm (and hormones).

nsbTraps: Gametes are haploid; the zygote is diploid. Don't say the egg or sperm is diploid.
Not all reproduction is sexual—many organisms can reproduce asexually (e.g., budding, cloning).
didYouKnow: Identical twins come from one zygote that splits; fraternal twins come from two fertilized eggs.
Some animals can change sex or reproduce without a partner (asexually).

subject: Life Science
title: Ecology & Ecosystems
whatIsIt: Ecology is the study of how organisms interact with each other and their environment. An ecosystem includes all the living (biotic) and nonliving (abiotic) things in an area and the energy and nutrients flowing through them.
howItWorks: Producers (plants, algae) capture energy from the sun and make organic matter. Consumers eat producers or other consumers. Decomposers break down dead matter and return nutrients to the soil. Food chains show one path of energy; food webs show many interconnected chains. Energy is lost at each trophic level (only about 10% passes up); nutrients cycle (carbon, nitrogen, water cycles).
realWorldExample: In a pond, algae are producers; small fish eat algae; big fish eat small fish. When any of them die, bacteria and fungi decompose them. The same nutrients are used again.

keyTerms.definition: Organism that makes its own food (usually by photosynthesis); base of the food chain.
Organism that eats other organisms for energy.
Organism that breaks down dead matter and recycles nutrients.
Path of energy from producer to consumer to higher consumers.
Position in a food chain (e.g., producer, primary consumer, secondary consumer).
All living and nonliving things in an area and their interactions.

nsbTraps: Energy flows one way (sun → producers → consumers); nutrients cycle (decomposers return them).
Top predators have less total energy available—that's why there are fewer of them.
didYouKnow: A single food web can have hundreds of species. Removing one can affect many others.
The energy in your food originally came from the sun, captured by plants or algae.

subject: Life Science
title: Biomes
whatIsIt: Biomes are large regions with similar climate, plants, and animals. Examples include tundra, taiga, temperate forest, tropical rainforest, grassland, desert, and aquatic biomes (freshwater and marine).
howItWorks: Climate (temperature and precipitation) mainly determines biomes. Latitude, elevation, and geography also matter. Each biome has characteristic plants and animals adapted to that climate. Tropical rainforests have high rain and biodiversity; deserts have little rain and organisms adapted to save water; tundra is cold with permafrost and short growing seasons.
realWorldExample: Cacti are adapted to deserts (store water, spines reduce water loss). Polar bears are adapted to the Arctic (thick fur, fat). You wouldn't find a cactus in the tundra or a polar bear in the Sahara.

keyTerms.definition: Large region with similar climate and characteristic communities of plants and animals.
Cold biome with permafrost, short summers, and low diversity.
Biome with high rainfall and very high biodiversity (tropical or temperate).
Biome with very low precipitation; organisms are adapted to conserve water.
Trait that helps an organism survive in its environment.

nsbTraps: Biome is not the same as ecosystem—biome is broader (e.g., 'tropical rainforest' is a biome; one patch of it is an ecosystem).
Aquatic biomes (ocean, lake, wetland) are also biomes—not just land.
didYouKnow: The Amazon rainforest produces a large amount of the world's oxygen and holds huge biodiversity.
Permafrost in the tundra stores a lot of carbon; if it thaws, it could affect global climate.

subject: Life Science
title: Population Ecology
whatIsIt: Population ecology studies how populations (groups of the same species in an area) change over time—births, deaths, immigration, emigration—and what limits their size, such as carrying capacity and interactions with other species.
howItWorks: Population growth depends on birth rate, death rate, and movement in or out. In ideal conditions, populations can grow exponentially. In nature, limiting factors (food, space, disease, predators) slow growth; the population may level off at the carrying capacity (the max the environment can support). Predator-prey cycles can cause populations to rise and fall in patterns. Competition (within or between species) also limits population size.
realWorldExample: When deer have plenty of food and few predators, their population can explode. When wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone, elk behavior and plant growth changed—showing how predators affect whole ecosystems.

keyTerms.definition: Maximum population size an environment can support over time.
Something that limits population growth (e.g., food, space, predators).
Pattern where predator and prey populations rise and fall in relation to each other.
Growth at a constant rate; population size increases faster and faster until limited.
When organisms need the same limited resource; can be within or between species.

nsbTraps: Carrying capacity is not the same as 'maximum possible'—it's what the environment can sustain long-term.
Predator and prey populations are linked; when prey drop, predators may drop too, then prey can recover.
didYouKnow: Human population growth has been exponential for the last few centuries; we're now over 8 billion.
In a classic experiment, predator and prey (e.g., lynx and hare) show clear cycles in population graphs.

subject: Life Science
title: Symbiosis
whatIsIt: Symbiosis is a close, long-term relationship between two different species. The main types are mutualism (both benefit), commensalism (one benefits, the other is unaffected), and parasitism (one benefits, the other is harmed).
howItWorks: In mutualism, both species gain—e.g., bees get nectar and flowers get pollinated. In commensalism, one benefits and the other isn't helped or hurt—e.g., a bird nesting in a tree. In parasitism, the parasite benefits (gets food or shelter) and the host is harmed—e.g., tapeworms in intestines, ticks on mammals. Symbiosis can shape evolution and ecosystem structure.
realWorldExample: Lichens are mutualism between a fungus and an alga. Remora fish attach to sharks for rides (commensalism). Fleas on a dog are parasites.

keyTerms.definition: Symbiosis where both species benefit.
Symbiosis where one benefits and the other is unaffected.
Symbiosis where one benefits (parasite) and the other is harmed (host).
Organism that a parasite lives on or in and gets resources from.
Organism that lives on or in another and harms it while benefiting.

nsbTraps: Commensalism is 'one benefits, one unaffected'—not 'one benefits, one is hurt' (that's parasitism).
Predation is not usually called symbiosis—symbiosis implies a close, ongoing relationship.
didYouKnow: Your gut bacteria are mutualists—you give them a home and food; they help you digest and make some vitamins.
Some ants 'farm' aphids and protect them in return for sugary honeydew—a kind of mutualism.

subject: Life Science
title: Biodiversity & Conservation
whatIsIt: Biodiversity is the variety of life—different species, genetic diversity within species, and variety of ecosystems. Conservation is the effort to protect and preserve biodiversity and ecosystems for the future.
howItWorks: Biodiversity is important for ecosystem health: different species play different roles, and variety can help ecosystems recover from disturbance. Threats include habitat loss, pollution, climate change, overharvesting, and invasive species. Conservation uses protected areas, laws, breeding programs, and habitat restoration. Endangered species are at risk of extinction; extinct means gone forever.
realWorldExample: Coral reefs have high biodiversity and support many fish and other species; when reefs die, those species suffer. Zoos and seed banks help save endangered species. Planting native plants helps local biodiversity.

keyTerms.definition: Variety of life at all levels: species, genes, and ecosystems.
Species at risk of becoming extinct.
When a species no longer exists anywhere on Earth.
Destruction or fragmentation of where organisms live; a major cause of extinction.
Non-native species that spread and harm native species or ecosystems.
Protection and sustainable use of natural resources and biodiversity.

nsbTraps: Endangered means at risk; extinct means already gone. Don't use them interchangeably.
Not all non-native species are invasive—only those that cause harm when they spread.
didYouKnow: We are in what some scientists call the sixth mass extinction—mainly due to human activity.
Protecting keystone species (which have a big effect on the ecosystem) can help many other species.

subject: Physical Science
title: Motion & Kinematics
whatIsIt: Motion describes how an object's position changes over time. Kinematics is the study of motion without considering the forces that cause it.
howItWorks: Speed is distance divided by time. Velocity is speed with direction. Acceleration is how quickly velocity changes. Distance-time graphs show position over time; the slope gives speed.
realWorldExample: A car's speedometer shows speed; when you brake, you feel acceleration (negative, because you're slowing down).

keyTerms.definition: Distance traveled per unit time.
Speed in a given direction.
Rate of change of velocity.

nsbTraps: Speed is a scalar (no direction); velocity is a vector (has direction).
didYouKnow: Constant velocity means zero acceleration; constant speed in a straight line.

subject: Physical Science
title: Newton's Three Laws of Motion
whatIsIt: Newton's three laws describe how forces affect the motion of objects. They are the foundation of classical mechanics.
howItWorks: First law: An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity unless acted on by a net force. Second law: F = ma (force equals mass times acceleration). Third law: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.
realWorldExample: When you push a shopping cart, it accelerates (second law). When you step off a boat, the boat moves backward (third law).

keyTerms.definition: Resistance to change in motion; from Newton's first law.
The vector sum of all forces acting on an object.

nsbTraps: Weight is a force (mg); mass is not. Don't confuse them.
didYouKnow: In outer space, with no friction, a small push can keep an object moving forever (first law).

subject: Chemistry
title: Atomic Structure
whatIsIt: Atoms are made of protons and neutrons in the nucleus, and electrons in shells around it. The number of protons defines the element.
howItWorks: Protons have positive charge, neutrons are neutral, electrons are negative. In a neutral atom, protons = electrons. The atomic number is the number of protons; mass number is protons + neutrons.
realWorldExample: Carbon has 6 protons; any atom with 6 protons is carbon, whether it has 6, 7, or 8 neutrons (isotopes).

keyTerms.definition: Positively charged subatomic particle in the nucleus.
Neutral subatomic particle in the nucleus.
Negatively charged particle outside the nucleus.

nsbTraps: Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
didYouKnow: Most of an atom's volume is empty space; the nucleus is tiny compared to the electron cloud.

subject: Chemistry
title: The Periodic Table
whatIsIt: The periodic table organizes all known elements by atomic number and groups elements with similar properties into columns.
howItWorks: Rows are periods (same number of electron shells); columns are groups (same number of valence electrons, so similar chemistry). Metals are on the left, nonmetals on the right, metalloids between.
realWorldExample: Group 1 (alkali metals) all have one valence electron and are highly reactive; Group 18 (noble gases) have full shells and are stable.

keyTerms.definition: A horizontal row on the periodic table.
A vertical column; elements in a group share similar properties.

nsbTraps: Atomic number is protons; atomic mass is roughly protons + neutrons. Don't confuse them.
didYouKnow: Mendeleev left gaps for undiscovered elements and predicted their properties.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Earth's Layers
whatIsIt: Earth has a thin crust, a thick mantle, a liquid outer core, and a solid inner core. The core is mostly iron and nickel.
howItWorks: The crust is solid rock. The mantle is solid but can flow slowly. The outer core is liquid metal and generates Earth's magnetic field. The inner core is solid due to extreme pressure.
realWorldExample: Earthquakes send waves through these layers; how the waves bend tells us about each layer's density and state.

keyTerms.definition: Outermost solid layer of Earth.
Thick layer between crust and core.
Center of Earth; outer liquid, inner solid.

nsbTraps: The mantle is solid, not liquid; it flows very slowly over long time scales.
didYouKnow: The inner core may be as hot as the surface of the sun.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Plate Tectonics
whatIsIt: Earth's lithosphere is broken into plates that move slowly on the asthenosphere. Their movement causes earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building.
howItWorks: Convection in the mantle drives plate motion. At divergent boundaries plates move apart; at convergent they collide (subduction or mountains); at transform boundaries they slide past each other.
realWorldExample: The Pacific Ring of Fire is where many plates meet; that's why there are so many earthquakes and volcanoes there.

keyTerms.definition: Rigid outer layer including crust and upper mantle.
When one plate sinks beneath another.

nsbTraps: Continental drift and plate tectonics are related; the theory was refined to include ocean floors.
didYouKnow: The Himalayas are still rising as India pushes into Asia.

subject: Energy
title: Forms of Energy
whatIsIt: Energy exists in many forms: kinetic (motion), potential (stored), thermal, chemical, nuclear, electrical, and radiant. Energy can be converted from one form to another.
howItWorks: The law of conservation of energy says total energy in a closed system stays constant. When you drop a ball, potential energy becomes kinetic; when it hits the ground, some becomes thermal and sound.
realWorldExample: A battery stores chemical energy and converts it to electrical energy to run a phone.

keyTerms.definition: Energy of motion.
Stored energy due to position or condition.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.

nsbTraps: Energy is conserved; it doesn't disappear, it just changes form (often to heat).
didYouKnow: Food calories are a measure of chemical potential energy.

subject: Energy
title: Energy Transformations & Conservation of Energy
whatIsIt: Energy can change from one form to another, but the total amount of energy in a closed system stays constant.
howItWorks: When you drop a ball, gravitational potential energy becomes kinetic energy. When it hits the ground, some becomes thermal and sound. No energy is lost—it's just converted. Friction often converts kinetic energy into heat.
realWorldExample: A roller coaster converts potential energy at the top of a hill into kinetic energy as it rolls down.

keyTerms.definition: A system that does not exchange energy with the outside.
Useful energy output divided by energy input.

nsbTraps: Energy is conserved; 'using' energy means converting it to a less useful form (often heat), not destroying it.
didYouKnow: Perpetual motion machines are impossible because of conservation of energy and friction.

subject: Math
title: Order of Operations (PEMDAS)
whatIsIt: PEMDAS tells us the order to perform operations: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division (left to right), Addition and Subtraction (left to right).
howItWorks: Do what's inside parentheses first. Then exponents. Then multiplication and division left to right. Finally addition and subtraction left to right.
realWorldExample: In 2 + 3 × 4, you multiply first (3 × 4 = 12), then add (2 + 12 = 14). If you added first you'd get 20, which is wrong.

keyTerms.definition: Order of operations: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiply, Divide, Add, Subtract.
A combination of numbers and operations.

nsbTraps: Multiplication and division have the same priority; do them left to right. Same for add and subtract.
didYouKnow: Some people remember PEMDAS as 'Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally.'

subject: Physical Science
title: Forces
whatIsIt: A force is a push or pull that can change an object's motion or shape. Gravity, friction, normal force, and tension are common forces.
howItWorks: Forces have magnitude and direction (they're vectors). Gravity pulls objects toward Earth (F = mg). Friction opposes motion between surfaces. The normal force is the support force perpendicular to a surface. Tension is the force in a string or rope. Net force determines acceleration (F = ma).
realWorldExample: When you stand on the floor, the normal force from the floor balances gravity. When you pull a wagon, tension in the rope accelerates it; friction at the wheels opposes the motion.

keyTerms.definition: Force of attraction between masses; on Earth, pulls objects downward.
Force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact.
Perpendicular force a surface exerts on an object resting on it.
Force transmitted through a string, rope, or cable when pulled.

nsbTraps: Weight is a force (mg); mass is not. Normal force is not always equal to weight—e.g., on an incline.
didYouKnow: Friction can be helpful—without it you couldn't walk or brake a car.

subject: Physical Science
title: Work, Energy & Power
whatIsIt: Work is done when a force moves an object in the direction of the force. Energy is the ability to do work. Power is how fast work is done.
howItWorks: Work W = F × d (force times distance in the direction of the force). If the force is at an angle, use the component in the direction of motion. Power P = work ÷ time (or P = F × v). The unit of work and energy is the joule; power is watts (joules per second).
realWorldExample: Lifting a book does work against gravity. A more powerful motor can do the same work in less time.

keyTerms.definition: Force times distance in the direction of the force; measured in joules.
Unit of work and energy; 1 J = 1 N·m.
Rate of doing work; measured in watts (W = J/s).

nsbTraps: No work is done if the object doesn't move in the direction of the force—holding a heavy bag still does no work.
didYouKnow: A watt is named after James Watt; a 100 W light bulb uses 100 joules per second.

subject: Physical Science
title: Kinetic & Potential Energy
whatIsIt: Kinetic energy is energy of motion (KE = ½mv²). Potential energy is stored energy—gravitational PE = mgh, elastic PE in springs.
howItWorks: The faster or heavier an object, the more kinetic energy. Gravitational potential energy depends on mass, height, and g. When an object falls, PE is converted to KE. Elastic potential energy is ½kx² for a spring (k = spring constant).
realWorldExample: A roller coaster at the top of a hill has maximum PE; at the bottom it has maximum KE. A stretched rubber band has elastic PE.

keyTerms.definition: Energy of motion; KE = ½mv².
Stored energy due to height; PE = mgh.
Energy stored in stretched or compressed springs.

nsbTraps: PE depends on the reference level—choose where h = 0 consistently. Double the speed means four times the KE.
didYouKnow: Energy is a scalar—it has no direction, only magnitude.

subject: Physical Science
title: Simple Machines
whatIsIt: Simple machines make work easier by changing the size or direction of the force. The six types are lever, pulley, inclined plane, wheel and axle, wedge, and screw.
howItWorks: They don't reduce the total work (work in = work out, ignoring friction) but they trade force for distance or vice versa. A lever has a fulcrum; moving the fulcrum changes the mechanical advantage. A pulley can change direction or multiply force. Inclined planes reduce the force needed to lift by increasing distance.
realWorldExample: Scissors are double levers. A ramp is an inclined plane. A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder.

keyTerms.definition: Rigid bar that pivots on a fulcrum to multiply force or distance.
Wheel with a groove for a rope; can change direction or provide mechanical advantage.
Sloped surface that reduces the force needed to lift an object.
Ratio of output force to input force (or input distance to output distance).

nsbTraps: Simple machines don't create energy—they trade force for distance. Ideal MA ignores friction.
didYouKnow: Archimedes said he could move the Earth with a lever long enough.

subject: Physical Science
title: Momentum & Impulse
whatIsIt: Momentum is mass times velocity (p = mv). Impulse is the change in momentum, equal to force times time (J = FΔt).
howItWorks: Momentum is conserved in a closed system with no net external force—total p before = total p after. Impulse = FΔt = Δp. A large force for a short time can give the same impulse as a small force for a long time (e.g., airbags extend the time to reduce force).
realWorldExample: When a baseball bat hits a ball, the impulse changes the ball's momentum. Catching a ball with bent arms extends the time and reduces the force on your hand.

keyTerms.definition: Mass times velocity; p = mv; a vector.
Change in momentum; J = FΔt = Δp.
In a closed system with no net external force, total momentum is constant.

nsbTraps: Momentum is a vector—direction matters. In collisions, total momentum is conserved, not necessarily kinetic energy.
didYouKnow: Rocket propulsion works by conservation of momentum—the rocket pushes exhaust backward, so the rocket moves forward.

subject: Physical Science
title: Waves: Properties
whatIsIt: Waves transfer energy without transferring matter. They have wavelength, frequency, amplitude, and speed.
howItWorks: Wavelength (λ) is the distance between two similar points. Frequency (f) is how many waves pass per second (Hz). Speed v = fλ. Amplitude is the maximum displacement from rest—it relates to energy. Transverse waves (e.g., light) oscillate perpendicular to direction of travel; longitudinal (e.g., sound) oscillate parallel.
realWorldExample: Ripples on water, sound, and light are all waves. A higher frequency sound has a higher pitch.

keyTerms.definition: Distance between two consecutive similar points on a wave (e.g., crest to crest).
Number of waves per second; unit is hertz (Hz).
Maximum displacement from equilibrium; related to wave energy.
v = fλ; speed of a wave depends on the medium.

nsbTraps: When a wave enters a new medium, frequency usually stays the same but wavelength and speed can change.
didYouKnow: Ocean waves are a combination of transverse and longitudinal motion.

subject: Physical Science
title: Sound Waves
whatIsIt: Sound is a longitudinal wave that travels through a medium (air, water, solid). Pitch is related to frequency; volume (loudness) is related to amplitude.
howItWorks: Vibrating objects create compressions and rarefactions in the medium. Higher frequency means higher pitch. The Doppler effect: when source or listener moves, the perceived frequency changes (e.g., siren sounds higher as it approaches). Sound cannot travel in a vacuum.
realWorldExample: A guitar string vibrates to produce sound. An ambulance siren sounds higher when it's coming toward you and lower when it passes.

keyTerms.definition: How high or low a sound is; determined by frequency.
Change in perceived frequency when source or observer is moving.
Wave in which the medium vibrates parallel to the direction of travel.

nsbTraps: Sound needs a medium; light can travel in a vacuum. Pitch is frequency; loudness is amplitude.
didYouKnow: Humans hear roughly 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz; ultrasound is above our range.

subject: Physical Science
title: Light & Electromagnetic Spectrum
whatIsIt: Light is an electromagnetic wave. The EM spectrum includes radio, microwave, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays—all the same type of wave but different wavelengths and frequencies.
howItWorks: EM waves don't need a medium; they travel at the speed of light in a vacuum (c ≈ 3×10⁸ m/s). Visible light is a small part of the spectrum. Higher frequency means higher energy (E = hf). Wavelength and frequency are related by c = fλ.
realWorldExample: Radio waves carry music to your phone. Infrared is heat you feel. UV from the sun can sunburn. X-rays pass through soft tissue but not bone.

keyTerms.definition: Wave of electric and magnetic fields; includes light, radio, X-rays.
Distance for one cycle; shorter wavelength means higher frequency and energy.
Narrow range of the EM spectrum that human eyes can see (roughly 400–700 nm).

nsbTraps: All EM waves travel at the same speed in a vacuum. 'Light' in physics often means all EM radiation, not just visible.
didYouKnow: The speed of light is the cosmic speed limit—nothing with mass can reach it.

subject: Physical Science
title: Reflection & Refraction
whatIsIt: Reflection is when light bounces off a surface (angle of incidence = angle of reflection). Refraction is when light bends as it enters a new medium (e.g., from air to water).
howItWorks: Law of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection. Refraction obeys Snell's law: n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂, where n is the index of refraction. When light goes into a denser medium (higher n), it bends toward the normal. Dispersion is when different wavelengths refract differently (e.g., rainbow).
realWorldExample: A mirror reflects your image. A straw in water looks bent because of refraction. Prisms separate white light into colors.

keyTerms.definition: Angle between incoming ray and the normal to the surface.
Bending of light when it passes from one medium to another.
n = c/v; how much light slows in a medium; n > 1.

nsbTraps: Reflection: angle is measured from the normal, not the surface. When n increases, light bends toward the normal.
didYouKnow: A mirage is caused by refraction in layers of air at different temperatures.

subject: Physical Science
title: Optics
whatIsIt: Optics is the study of how lenses and mirrors form images. Convex lenses converge light; concave lenses diverge it. Mirrors can be plane, concave (converging), or convex (diverging).
howItWorks: Convex (converging) lenses can form real or virtual images depending on object distance. Concave (diverging) lenses always form virtual, upright, smaller images. Focal length f is where parallel rays converge. Mirror and lens equations relate object distance, image distance, and focal length.
realWorldExample: Magnifying glasses are convex lenses. Car side mirrors are often convex to show a wider view. Concave mirrors are used in flashlights to focus light.

keyTerms.definition: Lens that is thicker in the center; converges parallel light to a focal point.
Lens that is thinner in the center; diverges light.
Distance from lens or mirror to the focal point.

nsbTraps: Real images can be projected on a screen; virtual images cannot. Convex lens can do either; concave lens only virtual.
didYouKnow: Your eye has a convex lens that focuses light onto the retina.

subject: Physical Science
title: Electricity
whatIsIt: Electricity involves electric charge, current (flow of charge), voltage (energy per charge), and resistance. Ohm's Law relates them: V = IR.
howItWorks: Charge is measured in coulombs; like charges repel, opposite attract. Current I is charge per time (amperes). Voltage V is potential difference (volts). Resistance R (ohms) opposes current. V = IR. Power P = IV = I²R.
realWorldExample: A battery provides voltage; when you connect a wire and bulb, current flows and the bulb lights. More resistance means less current for the same voltage.

keyTerms.definition: Rate of flow of electric charge; I = Q/t; unit ampere (A).
Electric potential difference; energy per charge; unit volt (V).
Opposition to current; R = V/I; unit ohm (Ω).
V = IR (voltage = current × resistance).

nsbTraps: Current is the same through series elements; voltage is the same across parallel branches. Don't confuse V and I.
didYouKnow: Static electricity is charge that isn't moving; current electricity is charge in motion.

subject: Physical Science
title: Circuits
whatIsIt: An electric circuit is a closed path for current. In series, components are in one loop (same current); in parallel, components have separate branches (same voltage across each branch).
howItWorks: Series: total R = R₁ + R₂ + …; same I through all. Parallel: 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + …; same V across each branch; currents add. Kirchhoff's rules: current into a junction = current out; sum of voltages around a loop = 0.
realWorldExample: Old Christmas lights in series: one bulb out, all go out. House wiring is parallel so each outlet gets the same voltage.

keyTerms.definition: Components in a single loop; same current through each.
Components in separate branches; same voltage across each branch.
Component that limits current; obeys Ohm's Law.

nsbTraps: In series, adding resistors increases total R. In parallel, adding resistors decreases total R.
didYouKnow: Batteries in series add voltage; in parallel they can provide more current for the same voltage.

subject: Physical Science
title: Magnetism & Electromagnetism
whatIsIt: Magnets have north and south poles; like poles repel, opposite attract. Electric current produces a magnetic field; a changing magnetic field can induce current (electromagnetic induction).
howItWorks: Magnetic field lines go from N to S. A current in a wire creates a circular field around it. A solenoid (coil) acts like a bar magnet. Moving a magnet through a coil (or changing the field) induces a voltage and current—this is how generators work. Motors use the force on a current in a magnetic field to spin.
realWorldExample: Compass needles align with Earth's magnetic field. Generators convert motion to electricity; motors convert electricity to motion.

keyTerms.definition: Region around a magnet (or current) where magnetic force acts.
Magnet made by current in a coil; can be turned on and off.
Inducing voltage/current by changing magnetic flux through a loop.

nsbTraps: You can't have a single magnetic pole (monopole)—they come in N-S pairs. Right-hand rule gives field direction.
didYouKnow: Earth's magnetic field protects us from charged particles from the sun.

subject: Physical Science
title: Heat & Thermodynamics
whatIsIt: Heat is energy transferred due to temperature difference. The three ways are conduction (direct contact), convection (fluid flow), and radiation (EM waves).
howItWorks: Heat flows from hot to cold. Specific heat is the energy needed to raise 1 kg by 1°C—water has high specific heat. First law: energy is conserved (heat in = work out + change in internal energy). Second law: heat cannot spontaneously flow from cold to hot.
realWorldExample: A metal spoon in hot soup gets hot by conduction. Boiling water has convection currents. The sun warms Earth by radiation.

keyTerms.definition: Heat transfer by direct contact between particles.
Heat transfer by movement of a fluid (liquid or gas).
Heat transfer by electromagnetic waves; no medium needed.
Energy per mass per temperature change; water has high specific heat.

nsbTraps: Temperature and heat are different—temperature is average KE; heat is energy transferred. Objects don't 'contain heat' in the same way they contain mass.
didYouKnow: Thermal expansion: most materials expand when heated—why bridges have expansion joints.

subject: Physical Science
title: States of Matter & Phase Changes
whatIsIt: The three common states are solid, liquid, and gas. Phase changes (melting, freezing, boiling, condensation, sublimation) occur at fixed temperatures when energy is added or removed.
howItWorks: Solids have fixed shape and volume; liquids have fixed volume but take container shape; gases fill the container. Melting/freezing at melting point; boiling/condensation at boiling point. During a phase change, temperature stays constant while energy goes into breaking or forming bonds. Sublimation is solid to gas (e.g., dry ice).
realWorldExample: Ice melts at 0°C; water boils at 100°C. Sweat evaporating cools you because it takes heat from your skin.

keyTerms.definition: Phase change from solid to liquid.
Phase change from liquid to gas at the boiling point.
Phase change directly from solid to gas (e.g., dry ice).

nsbTraps: During a phase change, temperature doesn't change even though you're adding heat—the energy goes into the phase change.
didYouKnow: Deposition is the reverse of sublimation—gas to solid (e.g., frost).

subject: Physical Science
title: Pressure & Fluids
whatIsIt: Pressure is force per unit area (P = F/A). Fluids (liquids and gases) exert pressure. Pascal's law: pressure in a fluid is transmitted equally in all directions. Buoyancy and Archimedes' principle explain why things float.
howItWorks: Pressure in a fluid increases with depth (P = ρgh for a liquid). Pascal's principle: applied pressure in an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished. Archimedes' principle: buoyant force = weight of fluid displaced. An object floats if its density is less than the fluid's.
realWorldExample: Dams are thicker at the bottom because pressure increases with depth. Submarines control buoyancy by changing the amount of water in ballast tanks.

keyTerms.definition: Force per unit area; P = F/A; unit pascal (Pa).
Pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted equally to every part.
Buoyant force on an object equals the weight of fluid it displaces.

nsbTraps: Pressure depends on depth and density, not total volume. Buoyancy depends on displaced volume, not the object's weight alone.
didYouKnow: Hydraulic brakes use Pascal's principle—small force on a small area becomes large force on a large area.

subject: Physical Science
title: Nuclear Physics Basics
whatIsIt: Nuclear physics involves the nucleus—fission (splitting heavy nuclei), fusion (combining light nuclei), and radioactive decay (unstable nuclei emitting particles).
howItWorks: Fission: a heavy nucleus (e.g., uranium) splits into smaller nuclei plus neutrons and energy. Fusion: light nuclei (e.g., hydrogen) combine to form heavier nuclei and release energy (powers the sun). Radioactive decay: alpha (helium nucleus), beta (electron or positron), gamma (high-energy photon)—each changes the nucleus.
realWorldExample: Nuclear power plants use fission. The sun uses fusion. Radon in basements is from decay of uranium in rock.

keyTerms.definition: Splitting of a heavy nucleus into smaller parts; releases energy.
Combining light nuclei into heavier ones; releases energy (e.g., in the sun).
Unstable nucleus emits particles or radiation to become more stable.

nsbTraps: Fission and fusion are opposite—fission splits, fusion combines. Both can release energy in the right conditions.
didYouKnow: Half-life is the time for half of a radioactive sample to decay—it's constant for each isotope.

subject: Chemistry
title: Elements, Compounds & Mixtures
whatIsIt: An element is a pure substance made of one type of atom. A compound is two or more elements chemically bonded in fixed ratios. A mixture is a combination of substances not chemically bonded.
howItWorks: Elements are on the periodic table (e.g., oxygen, carbon). Compounds have a fixed composition (e.g., H₂O is always 2:1 H to O). Mixtures can be homogeneous (same throughout, e.g., salt water) or heterogeneous (e.g., salad). Compounds can only be separated by chemical means; mixtures by physical means (filtering, distillation).
realWorldExample: Air is a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen, and other gases. Table salt is the compound NaCl. Gold is an element.

keyTerms.definition: Pure substance made of one type of atom; cannot be broken down by chemical means.
Substance made of two or more elements in a fixed ratio; can be broken down chemically.
Combination of substances not chemically bonded; can be separated physically.

nsbTraps: Compounds have fixed composition; mixtures can vary. Don't confuse compound with mixture.
didYouKnow: Water is a compound; seawater is a mixture (water plus salts and other substances).

subject: Chemistry
title: Chemical Bonds
whatIsIt: Chemical bonds hold atoms together in compounds. Ionic bonds form when electrons are transferred (metal + nonmetal). Covalent bonds form when electrons are shared (often nonmetal + nonmetal). Hydrogen bonds are weak attractions between molecules.
howItWorks: Ionic: one atom donates electrons, another accepts; result is ions that attract (e.g., Na⁺Cl⁻). Covalent: atoms share electron pairs; can be single, double, or triple bonds. Polar covalent means unequal sharing (e.g., H₂O). Hydrogen bonds: H bonded to O, N, or F is attracted to another O, N, or F—important in DNA and water.
realWorldExample: Table salt is ionic. Sugar and water have covalent bonds. Hydrogen bonds give water its high boiling point and hold DNA strands together.

keyTerms.definition: Bond formed by transfer of electrons; typically metal + nonmetal.
Bond formed by sharing electron pairs between atoms.
Weak attraction between H (on O, N, F) and another O, N, or F.

nsbTraps: Ionic compounds form crystals and often dissolve in water; covalent molecules can be gases, liquids, or solids. Don't say 'covalent crystal' when you mean ionic.
didYouKnow: The strength of chemical bonds is why some reactions release energy (bonds formed) and others absorb it (bonds broken).

subject: Chemistry
title: Chemical Reactions
whatIsIt: A chemical reaction rearranges atoms; reactants become products. The number of each type of atom is conserved—equations must be balanced.
howItWorks: Reactants are on the left, products on the right. Coefficients show how many of each molecule (e.g., 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O). Subscripts show atoms per molecule and cannot be changed when balancing—only coefficients can. Balance one element at a time.
realWorldExample: Burning: fuel + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O. Rusting: iron + oxygen → iron oxide. Photosynthesis and respiration are chemical reactions.

keyTerms.definition: Starting substance in a chemical reaction (left side of equation).
Substance produced in a reaction (right side).
Equation where the number of each type of atom is the same on both sides.

nsbTraps: Never change subscripts to balance—that changes the compound. Only change coefficients.
didYouKnow: Catalysts speed up reactions but are not consumed—they appear in the equation but can be written over the arrow.

subject: Chemistry
title: Types of Chemical Reactions
whatIsIt: Common types include synthesis (A + B → C), decomposition (C → A + B), single displacement (A + BC → AC + B), double displacement (AB + CD → AD + CB), and combustion (fuel + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O).
howItWorks: Synthesis combines two or more into one. Decomposition breaks one into two or more. Single displacement: one element replaces another in a compound. Double displacement: ions swap partners. Combustion: reaction with oxygen, often producing CO₂ and H₂O.
realWorldExample: Rust is synthesis (iron + oxygen). Hydrogen peroxide decomposing is decomposition. Burning wood is combustion.

keyTerms.definition: Reaction where two or more substances combine to form one product.
Reaction where one substance breaks into two or more.
Reaction with oxygen; often releases heat and light; produces CO₂ and H₂O for organic fuels.

nsbTraps: Combustion always involves O₂ as a reactant. Double displacement often forms a precipitate (solid) or water.
didYouKnow: Many reactions in your body are oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Acids & Bases
whatIsIt: Acids donate H⁺ (protons); bases accept H⁺ or donate OH⁻. The pH scale (0–14) measures acidity: pH < 7 is acid, 7 is neutral, > 7 is base.
howItWorks: Strong acids fully ionize in water (e.g., HCl → H⁺ + Cl⁻). Strong bases fully dissociate (e.g., NaOH → Na⁺ + OH⁻). pH = -log[H⁺]; each step is 10×. Neutralization: acid + base → salt + water. Indicators (e.g., litmus, phenolphthalein) change color with pH.
realWorldExample: Lemon juice and vinegar are acids. Soap and baking soda are bases. Stomach acid is HCl; antacids are bases that neutralize it.

keyTerms.definition: Measure of acidity; pH = -log[H⁺]; 7 is neutral, <7 acid, >7 base.
Reaction of acid and base to form salt and water.
Substance that changes color with pH (e.g., litmus).

nsbTraps: pH 4 is 10× more acidic than pH 5, not 1×. Don't confuse strength (degree of ionization) with concentration.
didYouKnow: Buffers resist pH change—blood has buffers to keep pH around 7.4.

subject: Chemistry
title: The Mole & Molar Mass
whatIsIt: The mole is a count of particles: 1 mole = 6.02×10²³ particles (Avogadro's number). Molar mass is the mass of one mole of a substance (g/mol)—numerically equal to the formula mass in amu.
howItWorks: Formula mass (or molecular mass) is the sum of atomic masses in the formula. Molar mass in g/mol has the same number. Moles = mass ÷ molar mass. Number of particles = moles × 6.02×10²³.
realWorldExample: One mole of carbon-12 is 12 grams. One mole of water is 18 g and contains 6.02×10²³ H₂O molecules.

keyTerms.definition: Amount of substance containing Avogadro's number (6.02×10²³) of particles.
Mass of one mole of a substance; g/mol; same number as formula mass in amu.
6.02×10²³; number of particles in one mole.

nsbTraps: Molar mass of O₂ is 32 g/mol (two oxygen atoms), not 16. Always use the formula.
didYouKnow: The mole lets chemists count atoms by weighing—you can't count 10²³ atoms one by one.

subject: Chemistry
title: States of Matter at the Molecular Level
whatIsIt: In solids, particles are close and vibrate in place. In liquids, they slide past each other. In gases, they move freely and are far apart.
howItWorks: Kinetic molecular theory: particles are in constant motion; temperature is related to average kinetic energy. Solids have strong attractions and fixed positions; liquids have moderate attractions; gases have weak attractions and fill the container. Pressure in a gas comes from collisions with the walls.
realWorldExample: Ice (solid) has ordered molecules; water (liquid) has molecules that can flow; steam (gas) has molecules moving fast and far apart.

keyTerms.definition: Model that explains gas behavior: particles in constant motion, collisions are elastic.
In gases, caused by collisions of particles with the container walls.

nsbTraps: Gas particles do have volume and attractions—ideal gas model ignores them for simplicity. Real gases deviate at high P and low T.
didYouKnow: Absolute zero (0 K) is when particle motion is at a minimum (theoretical).

subject: Chemistry
title: Solutions & Solubility
whatIsIt: A solution is a homogeneous mixture of solute (dissolved) and solvent (does the dissolving). Solubility is how much solute can dissolve in a given amount of solvent at a given temperature.
howItWorks: Like dissolves like: polar solvents (e.g., water) dissolve polar and ionic solutes; nonpolar solvents dissolve nonpolar solutes. Concentration can be expressed as mass/volume, percent, or molarity (moles per liter). Saturated solution has maximum dissolved solute; adding more won't dissolve.
realWorldExample: Sugar dissolves in water. Oil doesn't dissolve in water (nonpolar vs polar). Carbonated soda has CO₂ dissolved under pressure.

keyTerms.definition: Substance that is dissolved in a solution.
Substance that does the dissolving (e.g., water in salt water).
Maximum amount of solute that can dissolve in a given amount of solvent at a given T.
Solution that has dissolved the maximum amount of solute possible.

nsbTraps: Increasing temperature usually increases solubility of solids in liquids but can decrease solubility of gases.
didYouKnow: Supersaturated solutions hold more than the normal maximum—they're unstable and can crystallize suddenly.

subject: Chemistry
title: Oxidation & Reduction
whatIsIt: Oxidation is loss of electrons; reduction is gain of electrons. They always occur together (redox). The substance that is oxidized loses electrons to the substance that is reduced.
howItWorks: LEO says GER: Loss of Electrons is Oxidation; Gain of Electrons is Reduction. Oxidizing agent gets reduced (takes electrons); reducing agent gets oxidized (gives electrons). Oxidation numbers track electron transfer. Corrosion (e.g., rusting) is oxidation of metal.
realWorldExample: When iron rusts, iron is oxidized (loses electrons) and oxygen is reduced. Batteries use redox reactions to produce current.

keyTerms.definition: Loss of electrons; oxidation number increases.
Gain of electrons; oxidation number decreases.
Substance that accepts electrons; it gets reduced.
Substance that donates electrons; it gets oxidized.

nsbTraps: Reduction doesn't mean 'getting smaller'—it means gaining electrons. The name is historical.
didYouKnow: Photosynthesis and cellular respiration are both series of redox reactions.

subject: Chemistry
title: Organic Chemistry Basics
whatIsIt: Organic chemistry is the study of carbon-containing compounds. Carbon can form four bonds and long chains, so there are millions of organic compounds. Hydrocarbons contain only C and H; polymers are long chains of repeating units.
howItWorks: Hydrocarbons can be alkanes (single bonds), alkenes (double bonds), alkynes (triple bonds). Functional groups (e.g., -OH, -COOH) give molecules specific properties. Polymers are made of monomers joined together (e.g., plastics, proteins, DNA).
realWorldExample: Methane (CH₄) is natural gas. Ethanol has -OH. Plastics are polymers. Fats, proteins, and carbohydrates are organic.

keyTerms.definition: Compound containing only carbon and hydrogen.
Large molecule made of many repeating monomer units.
Compound containing carbon (with some exceptions like CO₂).

nsbTraps: Not all carbon compounds are from living things—plastics are synthetic organic compounds.
didYouKnow: DNA and proteins are organic polymers—life is based on carbon chemistry.

subject: Chemistry
title: Nuclear Chemistry
whatIsIt: Nuclear chemistry involves changes in the nucleus—radioactive decay, half-life, and uses in medicine and energy. Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.
howItWorks: Unstable (radioactive) nuclei decay by emitting alpha (⁴He nucleus), beta (electron or positron), or gamma (photon). Half-life is the time for half the nuclei to decay—it's constant for each isotope. Carbon-14 dating uses half-life to estimate age of organic material.
realWorldExample: Uranium-238 decays slowly (long half-life). Medical imaging uses radioactive tracers. Nuclear power uses fission.

keyTerms.definition: Atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but different number of neutrons.
Time for half of a radioactive sample to decay; constant for each isotope.
Emission of a helium nucleus (2 protons, 2 neutrons).

nsbTraps: Half-life doesn't depend on amount—whether you have 1 g or 1000 g, half decays in the same time.
didYouKnow: Carbon-14 has a half-life of about 5,730 years—used to date fossils and artifacts.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Earthquakes
whatIsIt: Earthquakes are sudden shaking of the ground caused by movement along faults when stress is released. Seismic waves travel through and along Earth's surface.
howItWorks: Energy is stored as stress when plates stick; when it's released, the fault slips and seismic waves radiate.
