P-waves (primary) are longitudinal and fastest; S-waves (secondary) are transverse and don't travel through liquid. Surface waves cause the most damage. The Richter scale (and moment magnitude) measure strength.
realWorldExample: The San Andreas Fault in California is a transform boundary where earthquakes are common. Tsunamis can be triggered by undersea quakes.

keyTerms.definition: Break in rock where movement can occur; earthquakes happen when fault slips.
Primary wave; longitudinal; travels through solids and liquids; fastest.
Secondary wave; transverse; travels only through solids.
Scale that measures earthquake magnitude (logarithmic).

nsbTraps: P-waves arrive first, then S-waves. S-waves don't go through the outer core—that's how we know it's liquid.
didYouKnow: The epicenter is the point on the surface above the focus (where the rupture starts underground).

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Volcanoes
whatIsIt: Volcanoes form where magma (molten rock below ground) reaches the surface. Lava is magma that has erupted. Volcanoes occur at divergent and convergent boundaries and at hot spots.
howItWorks: At convergent boundaries, subducting plate melts and magma rises. At divergent boundaries, magma rises at mid-ocean ridges. Hot spots are fixed plumes of mantle material (e.g., Hawaii). Eruptions can be explosive (viscous, gas-rich magma) or effusive (runny lava).
realWorldExample: Mount St. Helens is at a convergent boundary. Iceland is on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Hawaii is a hot-spot chain.

keyTerms.definition: Molten rock below Earth's surface.
Magma that has erupted onto the surface.
Fixed source of magma that can create a chain of volcanoes as the plate moves.

nsbTraps: Magma is underground; lava is on the surface. Not all magma becomes lava—some cools underground.
didYouKnow: The Ring of Fire around the Pacific has most of the world's volcanoes and earthquakes.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Rocks & the Rock Cycle
whatIsIt: Rocks are classified as igneous (from cooled magma/lava), sedimentary (from sediment or precipitation), or metamorphic (changed by heat and pressure). The rock cycle shows how they transform.
howItWorks: Igneous: magma/lava cools and crystallizes. Sedimentary: weathering and erosion produce sediment; compaction and cementation form rock. Metamorphic: existing rock is changed by heat and pressure without melting. Any rock can become any other type over geologic time.
realWorldExample: Granite is igneous. Sandstone is sedimentary. Marble is metamorphic limestone.

keyTerms.definition: Rock formed from cooling and solidification of magma or lava.
Rock formed from sediment or chemical precipitation; often in layers.
Rock changed by heat and pressure; can have foliation (layers).

nsbTraps: Sedimentary doesn't mean 'from sediment' only—chemical sedimentary rocks (e.g., rock salt) form from precipitation.
didYouKnow: Fossils are almost always found in sedimentary rock—igneous and metamorphic usually destroy them.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Minerals
whatIsIt: Minerals are naturally occurring, inorganic solids with a definite chemical composition and crystalline structure. Rocks are made of one or more minerals.
howItWorks: Minerals are identified by properties: hardness (Mohs scale), streak (color of powdered mineral), luster, cleavage/fracture, and sometimes taste or reaction to acid. Common minerals include quartz, feldspar, calcite, mica, and pyrite.
realWorldExample: Diamond and graphite are both pure carbon but different crystal structures—different minerals. Salt (halite) is a mineral.

keyTerms.definition: Naturally occurring, inorganic solid with definite composition and crystal structure.
Scale of mineral hardness from 1 (talc) to 10 (diamond).
Color of a mineral in powdered form; more reliable than surface color.

nsbTraps: Rocks are not minerals—rocks are aggregates of minerals. A few rocks are made of one mineral (e.g., limestone from calcite).
didYouKnow: There are over 5,000 known minerals, but only a few dozen are common in rocks.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Weathering & Erosion
whatIsIt: Weathering breaks down rock in place (physical or chemical). Erosion is the transport of weathered material by water, wind, ice, or gravity.
howItWorks: Physical weathering: frost wedging, root growth, abrasion—no chemical change. Chemical weathering: water, acid (e.g., from CO₂), oxygen break down minerals. Erosion moves the pieces. Deposition is when transported material is dropped.
realWorldExample: Potholes form from frost wedging. Rust on rocks is chemical weathering. Rivers carry sediment to the ocean.

keyTerms.definition: Breakdown of rock by mechanical processes (freeze-thaw, roots, abrasion).
Breakdown of rock by chemical reactions (dissolution, oxidation).
Transport of weathered material by water, wind, ice, or gravity.

nsbTraps: Weathering = in place; erosion = movement. Don't use them interchangeably.
didYouKnow: The Grand Canyon was carved by the Colorado River—erosion over millions of years.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Soil Formation
whatIsIt: Soil is a mixture of weathered rock, organic matter, water, and air. It forms slowly as rock weathers and organisms add organic material.
howItWorks: Parent rock weathers; plants and organisms add humus. Soil has layers (horizons): O (organic), A (topsoil), B (subsoil), C (weathered parent rock). Factors: climate, parent material, organisms, topography, time.
realWorldExample: Fertile farmland has thick, organic-rich topsoil. Desert soil may be thin and mineral-rich.

keyTerms.definition: Decayed organic matter in soil; dark, nutrient-rich.
Layer of soil with distinct properties (O, A, B, C).

nsbTraps: Soil is not just 'dirt'—it's a living system with bacteria, fungi, and invertebrates.
didYouKnow: It can take hundreds to thousands of years to form a few centimeters of topsoil.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: The Water Cycle
whatIsIt: Water cycles through evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff. The sun drives the cycle; water moves between ocean, atmosphere, land, and living things.
howItWorks: Evaporation: liquid to vapor (from oceans, lakes, plants—transpiration). Condensation: vapor to liquid (clouds form). Precipitation: rain, snow, etc. Runoff and infiltration return water to bodies of water or groundwater. The total amount of water on Earth is essentially constant.
realWorldExample: Ocean water evaporates; clouds form; rain falls on land; rivers carry water back to the ocean.

keyTerms.definition: Liquid water becoming water vapor; driven by heat.
Water vapor becoming liquid; forms clouds and dew.
Water falling from clouds as rain, snow, sleet, or hail.
Water vapor released by plants through their leaves.

nsbTraps: The water cycle has no start or end—it's a continuous loop. Transpiration is a major source of atmospheric water.
didYouKnow: The same water molecules have been cycling for billions of years—you might drink water a dinosaur drank.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Oceans
whatIsIt: Oceans cover most of Earth and affect climate, weather, and life. They have currents, tides, and distinct zones. Salinity and temperature vary.
howItWorks: Surface currents are driven by wind and the Coriolis effect; deep currents by density (temperature and salinity). Tides are caused mainly by the Moon's gravity (and the Sun's). The ocean floor has mid-ocean ridges, trenches, and abyssal plains.
realWorldExample: The Gulf Stream carries warm water north along the East Coast. Tides rise and fall roughly twice a day.

keyTerms.definition: Salt content of water; oceans are about 3.5% salt.
Flow of water in the ocean; surface or deep.
Rise and fall of sea level caused mainly by the Moon's gravity.

nsbTraps: Tides are not caused by the Moon 'pulling' water only—the whole Earth is pulled; the water bulges on both sides.
didYouKnow: The ocean absorbs a lot of CO₂—which affects ocean acidity and marine life.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Weather & Atmosphere
whatIsIt: The atmosphere has layers (troposphere, stratosphere, mesosphere, thermosphere). Weather is the short-term state of the atmosphere; climate is long-term average.
howItWorks: Troposphere: where we live; weather and clouds; temperature decreases with height. Stratosphere: contains ozone layer; temperature increases with height. Weather is driven by sun, water cycle, and air pressure differences.
realWorldExample: Storms form in the troposphere. Planes often fly in the lower stratosphere. The ozone layer protects us from UV.

keyTerms.definition: Lowest layer of atmosphere; where weather occurs; temp decreases with altitude.
Layer above troposphere; contains ozone; temp increases with altitude.
Region with high ozone (O₃) that absorbs UV radiation.

nsbTraps: Weather vs. climate: weather is day-to-day; climate is average over decades. One cold day doesn't disprove climate change.
didYouKnow: Most of the atmosphere's mass is in the troposphere—the first 10–15 km.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Weather Systems
whatIsIt: Weather is driven by air masses, fronts (boundaries between air masses), and pressure systems. High pressure usually means fair weather; low pressure often means clouds and precipitation.
howItWorks: Cold fronts: cold air advances and lifts warm air—often storms. Warm fronts: warm air overrides cold—slower, broader precipitation. High pressure: sinking air, clear skies. Low pressure: rising air, clouds. Clouds form when air rises and cools (adiabatic cooling).
realWorldExample: A cold front might bring thunderstorms. Hurricanes are intense low-pressure systems over warm ocean water.

keyTerms.definition: Boundary between two air masses of different temperature and humidity.
Area where air is sinking; generally fair weather.
Area where air is rising; often clouds and precipitation.

nsbTraps: Cold front = cold air advancing. Warm front = warm air advancing. Don't confuse the direction of movement.
didYouKnow: Weather maps show isobars (lines of equal pressure)—winds blow roughly parallel to them.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Climate & Climate Change
whatIsIt: Climate is the long-term average of weather in a region. Climate change is a shift in those averages—currently driven largely by increased greenhouse gases from human activity.
howItWorks: Greenhouse effect: certain gases (CO₂, methane, water vapor) trap heat in the atmosphere. More greenhouse gases mean more warming. Evidence: rising temperatures, melting ice, sea-level rise, more extreme events. Mitigation (reduce emissions) and adaptation (prepare for changes) are responses.
realWorldExample: The last century has warmed; glaciers are retreating; sea level is rising. Burning fossil fuels adds CO₂.

keyTerms.definition: Trapping of heat by certain gases in the atmosphere; natural and enhanced by human activity.
Long-term shift in climate patterns; currently refers to human-caused global warming.

nsbTraps: Climate and weather are different. One record cold day doesn't disprove global warming—it's about long-term trends.
didYouKnow: Earth's climate has changed before (ice ages), but current change is very fast and linked to CO₂ from fossil fuels.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: The Solar System
whatIsIt: The solar system includes the Sun, eight planets, dwarf planets (e.g., Pluto), moons, asteroids, and comets. Planets orbit the Sun; moons orbit planets.
howItWorks: Inner planets (Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars) are rocky. Outer planets (Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune) are gas giants (and ice). The asteroid belt is between Mars and Jupiter. The Kuiper belt and Oort cloud hold icy bodies. Orbits are elliptical (Kepler's laws).
realWorldExample: We live on the third planet. Jupiter is the largest. Comets have long, elliptical orbits and develop tails near the Sun.

keyTerms.definition: Body that orbits the Sun, is round, and has cleared its orbit (IAU definition).
Round body that orbits the Sun but has not cleared its orbit (e.g., Pluto).
Rocky body orbiting the Sun; most in the asteroid belt.

nsbTraps: Pluto is a dwarf planet, not a planet—not because it's small but because it hasn't cleared its orbit.
didYouKnow: The solar system is about 4.6 billion years old.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: The Sun
whatIsIt: The Sun is a star at the center of our solar system. It's powered by nuclear fusion in its core—hydrogen fusing into helium.
howItWorks: Core: fusion (extremely high T and P). Radiative and convective zones carry energy outward. Photosphere is the visible surface. Chromosphere and corona are outer layers. Sunspots are cooler regions; solar flares and coronal mass ejections are eruptions.
realWorldExample: Sunlight is energy from fusion that left the Sun about 8 minutes ago. Solar flares can affect satellites and power grids.

keyTerms.definition: Process in the Sun's core; hydrogen nuclei combine to form helium; releases energy.
Cooler, darker region on the Sun's surface; related to magnetic activity.
Sudden eruption of energy and particles from the Sun.

nsbTraps: The Sun is not on fire—it's fusion, not combustion. It's mostly hydrogen and helium.
didYouKnow: The Sun will run out of core hydrogen in billions of years and become a red giant.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Stars & the Life Cycle of Stars
whatIsIt: Stars are balls of gas that produce light and heat by fusion. They form from nebulae, spend most of their lives on the main sequence, and eventually die—outcome depends on mass.
howItWorks: Formation: nebula collapses; protostar; fusion begins → main sequence. Low-mass stars: red giant → white dwarf. High-mass: red supergiant → supernova → neutron star or black hole. Main sequence is the stable phase (H → He in core).
realWorldExample: The Sun is a main-sequence star. Betelgeuse is a red supergiant. The Crab Nebula is a supernova remnant.

keyTerms.definition: Phase where a star fuses hydrogen in its core; most of a star's life.
Phase when a star expands after core hydrogen is used; cooler surface, larger size.
Explosive death of a massive star; can outshine a galaxy briefly.
Dense remnant of a low-mass star after red giant phase.

nsbTraps: Not all stars become black holes—only the most massive. Sun-like stars become white dwarfs.
didYouKnow: We are made of 'star stuff'—elements heavier than hydrogen and helium were made in stars and supernovae.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Galaxies & the Universe
whatIsIt: Galaxies are huge collections of stars, gas, and dust. The Milky Way is our galaxy. The universe is expanding; the Big Bang is the leading theory for its origin.
howItWorks: Galaxy types: spiral (like Milky Way), elliptical, irregular. The universe began about 13.8 billion years ago in a hot, dense state and has been expanding since. Redshift of distant galaxies shows they're moving away. Cosmic microwave background is leftover radiation from the early universe.
realWorldExample: The Andromeda Galaxy is a spiral like ours. The universe is getting bigger; distant galaxies recede faster.

keyTerms.definition: Large system of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter bound by gravity.
Our galaxy; a spiral galaxy containing the solar system.
Theory that the universe began in a hot, dense state and has been expanding since.

nsbTraps: The Big Bang was not an explosion in space—it was the expansion of space itself.
didYouKnow: There are billions of galaxies, each with billions of stars.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Earth's Moon
whatIsIt: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. It has phases (due to the relative positions of Sun, Earth, Moon), causes tides, and can eclipse the Sun or be eclipsed by Earth.
howItWorks: Phases: new, waxing crescent, first quarter, waxing gibbous, full, waning gibbous, last quarter, waning crescent—cycle about 29.5 days. Lunar eclipse: Earth's shadow on the Moon (full moon). Solar eclipse: Moon blocks Sun (new moon). The Moon is tidally locked—same side faces Earth.
realWorldExample: We see different amounts of the lit half of the Moon each night. Eclipses don't happen every month because the Moon's orbit is tilted.

keyTerms.definition: Appearance of the Moon as seen from Earth (new, quarter, full, etc.).
Earth blocks sunlight from reaching the Moon; happens at full moon.
Moon blocks sunlight from reaching Earth; happens at new moon.

nsbTraps: Moon phases are not caused by Earth's shadow—that's an eclipse. Phases are due to how much of the sunlit side we see.
didYouKnow: The Moon is slowly moving away from Earth (a few cm per year).

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Space Exploration & Technology
whatIsIt: Spacecraft, telescopes, and satellites help us explore and use space. Robotic missions have visited planets and moons; humans have been to the Moon and live on the ISS.
howItWorks: Rockets use Newton's third law (expel mass backward to go forward). Orbit requires sufficient horizontal speed so the object 'falls around' Earth. Telescopes (optical, radio, space-based) collect light and other radiation. Satellites are used for communication, weather, GPS, and science.
realWorldExample: Mars rovers send back images and data. The Hubble and James Webb telescopes observe distant objects. GPS relies on satellites.

keyTerms.definition: Path of an object around another due to gravity; balance of forward motion and fall.
Object that orbits a planet; natural (e.g., Moon) or artificial (e.g., ISS).

nsbTraps: Astronauts in orbit are not 'weightless' because there's no gravity—they're in free fall (microgravity).
didYouKnow: The International Space Station orbits about 400 km above Earth and circles it roughly every 90 minutes.

subject: Earth & Space Science
title: Time, Seasons & Earth's Rotation/Revolution
whatIsIt: Earth rotates on its axis once per day (causing day and night). Earth revolves around the Sun once per year. The tilt of Earth's axis (about 23.5°) causes seasons.
howItWorks: Rotation: 24 hours; day and night. Revolution: 365.25 days; one year. The axis is tilted relative to the orbit—so when one hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun, it gets more direct sunlight and longer days (summer); the other has winter. Equinoxes: equal day/night. Solstices: longest/shortest day.
realWorldExample: When it's summer in the Northern Hemisphere, it's winter in the Southern—opposite tilts toward the Sun.

keyTerms.definition: Spinning of Earth on its axis; causes day and night.
Orbit of Earth around the Sun; causes the year and seasons (with tilt).
When the Sun is at its highest or lowest in the sky; longest or shortest day.
When day and night are equal length; Sun overhead at equator.

nsbTraps: Seasons are not caused by how close Earth is to the Sun—we're actually closer in January. Tilt is the key.
didYouKnow: The tilt is why we have different climate zones and the midnight sun in polar summer.

subject: Energy
title: Fossil Fuels
whatIsIt: Fossil fuels (coal, oil, natural gas) formed from ancient organic matter over millions of years. They store chemical energy and release it when burned.
howItWorks: Formation: dead organisms were buried and subjected to heat and pressure; organic matter became hydrocarbon-rich. Coal from plants; oil and natural gas from marine organisms. Burning (combustion) releases CO₂ and water plus heat. Pros: abundant, high energy density. Cons: nonrenewable, pollution, greenhouse gases.
realWorldExample: Gasoline in cars, coal in power plants, natural gas for heating and cooking.

keyTerms.definition: Solid fossil fuel; formed from plant matter; used for electricity.
Mostly methane; fossil fuel; burns cleaner than coal or oil.
Resource that cannot be replaced in a human timescale.

nsbTraps: Fossil fuels are not literally fossils—they're from ancient organic matter. Oil and gas are not 'dinosaurs'—mostly from plankton and plants.
didYouKnow: The U.S. and other countries are shifting to cleaner energy to reduce CO₂ emissions.

subject: Energy
title: Nuclear Energy
whatIsIt: Nuclear power plants use fission—splitting uranium nuclei—to heat water, make steam, and turn turbines to generate electricity. No CO₂ from the reaction, but there is radioactive waste.
howItWorks: Uranium-235 nuclei absorb neutrons and split; release more neutrons and energy. Chain reaction: neutrons cause more fissions. Control rods absorb neutrons to regulate. Heat from the reactor turns water to steam; steam drives a turbine connected to a generator.
realWorldExample: About 20% of U.S. electricity is from nuclear. France gets most of its electricity from nuclear.

keyTerms.definition: Splitting of a heavy nucleus; releases energy and neutrons.
When one fission causes more fissions; controlled in a reactor.
Material that absorbs neutrons; inserted/removed to control the reaction.

nsbTraps: Nuclear power does not produce greenhouse gases from the reaction—but mining and building plants have other impacts. Waste stays radioactive for a long time.
didYouKnow: Nuclear fusion (like in the Sun) is being researched for future power—it would produce less long-lived waste.

subject: Energy
title: Solar Energy
whatIsIt: Solar energy comes from the Sun. We capture it with photovoltaic (PV) cells (electricity) or solar thermal systems (heat). It's renewable and produces no direct emissions.
howItWorks: PV cells: sunlight knocks electrons loose in a semiconductor (e.g., silicon), creating electric current. Solar thermal: mirrors or collectors focus sunlight to heat a fluid, which can drive a turbine or provide hot water. Efficiency and output depend on location, angle, and weather.
realWorldExample: Rooftop solar panels on homes. Large solar farms in sunny regions. Solar water heaters.

keyTerms.definition: Converting light directly into electricity using semiconductor cells.
Using sunlight to heat a fluid; can generate electricity or provide heat.
Energy source that can be replenished in a human timescale (e.g., sun, wind).

nsbTraps: Solar doesn't work at night and is reduced on cloudy days—storage or backup is needed for 24/7 power.
didYouKnow: The amount of sunlight that hits Earth in an hour could meet global energy needs for a year—if we could capture and store it.

subject: Energy
title: Wind Energy
whatIsIt: Wind turbines convert the kinetic energy of moving air into electricity. Wind is caused by uneven heating of the Earth (sun). It's renewable and produces no direct emissions.
howItWorks: Wind turns the blades of a turbine; the rotor is connected to a generator that produces electricity. Larger and taller turbines capture more wind. Wind farms are often in windy areas (plains, coasts, offshore). Variable—wind doesn't blow constantly.
realWorldExample: Wind farms in Texas, Iowa, and offshore in Europe. Single turbines for homes or farms.

keyTerms.definition: Device with blades that turn when fluid (wind, water, steam) flows through; drives a generator.
The rotating part of a wind turbine (the blades and hub).

nsbTraps: Wind energy is indirect solar—sun heats Earth unevenly, causing wind. Not 'new' energy, just converted.
didYouKnow: Offshore wind is often stronger and more consistent than on land.

subject: Energy
title: Hydroelectric Power
whatIsIt: Hydroelectric power uses the energy of falling or flowing water to turn turbines and generate electricity. Dams store water and create height (potential energy) that becomes kinetic energy and then electricity.
howItWorks: Water behind a dam has gravitational potential energy. It flows through penstocks to turbines; the water's motion spins the turbines, which drive generators. Output depends on flow rate and height (head). Pumped storage: use excess electricity to pump water uphill; release it to generate when needed.
realWorldExample: Hoover Dam, Three Gorges Dam. Many countries get a large share of electricity from hydropower.

keyTerms.definition: Height of water above the turbine; more head means more potential energy.
Pipe that carries water from the reservoir to the turbine.

nsbTraps: Hydropower is renewable but dams can affect ecosystems and displace people—not without impacts.
didYouKnow: Hydropower is one of the oldest and largest sources of renewable electricity worldwide.

subject: Energy
title: Geothermal Energy
whatIsIt: Geothermal energy is heat from inside Earth. We use it for electricity (where hot rock or magma is close to the surface) or for heating and cooling (ground-source heat pumps).
howItWorks: In volcanic regions, hot water or steam from underground can drive turbines. In other places, heat pumps use the stable temperature of the ground a few meters down—cool in summer, warm in winter—to heat or cool buildings efficiently.
realWorldExample: Iceland gets much of its electricity and heat from geothermal. Heat pumps in homes use the ground as a heat source/sink.

keyTerms.definition: Relating to heat from Earth's interior.
Device that moves heat from one place to another; can heat or cool efficiently.

nsbTraps: Geothermal for electricity is limited to geologically active areas; heat pumps work almost anywhere.
didYouKnow: The core of Earth is as hot as the surface of the Sun—that heat slowly flows outward.

subject: Energy
title: Biomass & Biofuels
whatIsIt: Biomass is organic material (plants, animal waste) used for energy. Biofuels (e.g., ethanol, biodiesel) are fuels made from biomass. They can be renewable if the source is regrown.
howItWorks: Burning biomass releases stored chemical energy (like fossil fuels but from recent carbon). Ethanol is made by fermenting sugars (e.g., from corn). Biodiesel from vegetable oils or animal fats. Biogas from decomposition of waste. Carbon-neutral only if the CO₂ released is balanced by new growth.
realWorldExample: Ethanol in gasoline. Wood pellets for heating. Landfill gas for electricity.

keyTerms.definition: Organic material from plants or animals used as an energy source.
Fuel (e.g., ethanol, biodiesel) made from biomass.

nsbTraps: Biofuels are not automatically carbon-neutral—growing, processing, and transport use energy and land.
didYouKnow: Some airplanes are testing biofuels made from used cooking oil or algae.

subject: Energy
title: Energy Efficiency & Conservation
whatIsIt: Efficiency means using less energy to do the same task (e.g., LED vs incandescent). Conservation means using less energy overall (turning off lights, insulation). Both reduce demand and environmental impact.
howItWorks: Efficiency: better technology (motors, appliances, vehicles) converts more input energy to useful output; the rest is waste heat. Conservation: behavior and design (thermostats, insulation, less driving). Efficiency = useful output ÷ energy input.
realWorldExample: LED bulbs use much less electricity than incandescent for the same light. Insulation keeps heat in during winter.

keyTerms.definition: Ratio of useful energy output to energy input; higher is better.
Using less energy through behavior or design.

nsbTraps: Efficiency doesn't mean using zero energy—it means less waste. A 90% efficient heater still loses 10%.
didYouKnow: The U.S. DOE promotes energy efficiency—it's often the cheapest way to 'create' more energy (by saving it).

subject: Energy
title: The Electric Grid
whatIsIt: The electric grid is the network that delivers electricity from power plants to homes and businesses. It includes transmission (high voltage, long distance) and distribution (lower voltage, local).
howItWorks: Power plants generate AC electricity. Step-up transformers increase voltage for transmission (less loss over distance). Transmission lines carry power. Substations step voltage down. Distribution lines bring power to neighborhoods. Transformers at poles or pads step it down again for homes (e.g., 120 V).
realWorldExample: When you flip a switch, electricity flows from a power plant (maybe hundreds of miles away) through the grid to your outlet.

keyTerms.definition: Moving electricity at high voltage over long distances.
Delivering electricity at lower voltage to customers.
Device that increases or decreases AC voltage.

nsbTraps: AC is used for transmission because voltage can be easily changed with transformers—reducing current and losses.
didYouKnow: The U.S. grid has three main regions (Eastern, Western, Texas) that don't fully connect.

subject: Energy
title: DOE & U.S. Energy Policy Basics
whatIsIt: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) oversees energy research, nuclear security, and energy policy. U.S. energy policy affects what sources we use, efficiency standards, and climate goals.
howItWorks: DOE funds research on renewables, nuclear, fusion, and efficiency. It manages the nuclear weapons complex and cleanup. Policy (laws, regulations, incentives) can promote certain fuels, set vehicle efficiency standards, or support clean energy. The National Science Bowl is run by DOE.
realWorldExample: DOE research helped improve solar cells and batteries. Tax credits for electric vehicles are a policy tool.

keyTerms.definition: U.S. Department of Energy; oversees energy research and nuclear security.
Laws, regulations, and incentives that shape energy use and supply.

nsbTraps: DOE is not the same as EPA (environmental) or FERC (electricity markets)—each has a different role.
didYouKnow: The National Science Bowl is a DOE program to encourage students in science and math.

subject: Energy
title: Climate Change & Energy
whatIsIt: Burning fossil fuels is the main source of human-caused greenhouse gas emissions. Shifting to clean energy and using less energy can slow climate change.
howItWorks: CO₂ from burning coal, oil, and gas traps heat (greenhouse effect). To limit warming, we need to cut emissions: use renewables, nuclear, efficiency, and conservation. Carbon capture can reduce emissions from fossil plants. Adaptation (e.g., resilient grid) is also needed.
realWorldExample: Replacing coal plants with wind and solar reduces CO₂. Electric vehicles and heat pumps reduce fossil use.

keyTerms.definition: Gas that traps heat in the atmosphere (CO₂, methane, etc.).
Reducing or eliminating CO₂ emissions from energy and industry.

nsbTraps: Climate change is about long-term buildup of CO₂—one clean power plant helps but global action is needed.
didYouKnow: Many countries have pledged to reach net-zero emissions by mid-century to limit warming.

subject: Math
title: Number Theory
whatIsIt: Number theory studies integers: primes, factors, multiples, GCF (greatest common factor), and LCM (least common multiple).
howItWorks: A prime has exactly two factors (1 and itself). Factors divide evenly; multiples are the product with an integer. GCF: largest number that divides two or more numbers. LCM: smallest number that is a multiple of two or more numbers. Prime factorization (breaking into primes) helps find GCF and LCM.
realWorldExample: Simplifying fractions uses GCF. Adding fractions with different denominators uses LCM.

keyTerms.definition: Integer greater than 1 with only two factors: 1 and itself.
Greatest common factor; largest number that divides two or more numbers.
Least common multiple; smallest number that is a multiple of two or more numbers.

nsbTraps: 1 is not prime (only one factor). To find LCM, you need the highest power of each prime that appears.
didYouKnow: There are infinitely many primes—Euclid proved it over 2,000 years ago.

subject: Math
title: Fractions, Decimals & Percentages
whatIsIt: Fractions (a/b), decimals (e.g., 0.75), and percentages (e.g., 75%) are different ways to represent parts of a whole or ratios. They are equivalent and can be converted.
howItWorks: Fraction to decimal: divide numerator by denominator. Decimal to percent: multiply by 100. Percent to fraction: put over 100 and simplify. To add/subtract fractions, use a common denominator. To multiply fractions, multiply numerators and denominators. To divide, multiply by the reciprocal.
realWorldExample: Half = 1/2 = 0.5 = 50%. A 25% discount means you pay 75% of the price.

keyTerms.definition: Top number in a fraction; number of parts.
Bottom number in a fraction; total parts.
Flip of a fraction; a/b and b/a are reciprocals (product = 1).

nsbTraps: When adding fractions, don't add denominators—find a common denominator first. Percent change is (new - old)/old × 100.
didYouKnow: Repeating decimals (e.g., 0.333...) can be written as fractions (1/3).

subject: Math
title: Ratios & Proportions
whatIsIt: A ratio compares two quantities (e.g., 3:2 or 3/2). A proportion is an equation that two ratios are equal (e.g., a/b = c/d). Cross-multiply to solve.
howItWorks: Ratios can be simplified like fractions. In a proportion a/b = c/d, ad = bc (cross-multiplication). Use proportions for scale drawings, unit rates, and similar figures. Unit rate = amount per one unit (e.g., miles per gallon).
realWorldExample: If 2 apples cost $1, then 6 apples cost $3 (proportion). A map scale 1 inch = 10 miles is a ratio.

keyTerms.definition: Comparison of two quantities; can be written a:b or a/b.
Equation stating that two ratios are equal.
Rate per one unit (e.g., dollars per pound).

nsbTraps: Keep units consistent in a ratio. In a/b = c/d, cross-multiply gives ad = bc, not ac = bd.
didYouKnow: The golden ratio (about 1.618) appears in art, nature, and architecture.

subject: Math
title: Exponents & Scientific Notation
whatIsIt: Exponents show repeated multiplication: aⁿ = a × a × … × a (n times). Scientific notation writes numbers as a × 10ⁿ where 1 ≤ a < 10; used for very large or small numbers.
howItWorks: Rules: aᵐ·aⁿ = aᵐ⁺ⁿ; aᵐ/aⁿ = aᵐ⁻ⁿ; (aᵐ)ⁿ = aᵐⁿ; a⁰ = 1 (a ≠ 0); a⁻ⁿ = 1/aⁿ. Scientific notation: 3,000 = 3×10³; 0.004 = 4×10⁻³. Multiply: multiply the numbers and add exponents of 10.
realWorldExample: 2³ = 8. Speed of light ≈ 3×10⁸ m/s. Mass of an electron ≈ 9×10⁻³¹ kg.

keyTerms.definition: Number that shows how many times the base is used as a factor.
Number written as a × 10ⁿ where 1 ≤ a < 10; n is an integer.
Number that is multiplied by itself (e.g., in 2³, 2 is the base).

nsbTraps: (2³)² = 2⁶ (multiply exponents), not 2⁵. 2³ + 2² is not 2⁵—no rule for adding same base.
didYouKnow: Powers of 2 grow fast: 2¹⁰ = 1024 (about a thousand); 2²⁰ is about a million.

subject: Math
title: Square Roots & Cube Roots
whatIsIt: The square root of a number n is a number that when squared equals n (√n = r means r² = n). The cube root is the number that when cubed equals n.
howItWorks: √(a²) = |a|. √(ab) = √a·√b. √(a/b) = √a/√b. No negative under a square root in the reals. Cube roots can be negative (∛(-8) = -2). Perfect squares: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, … Perfect cubes: 1, 8, 27, …
realWorldExample: Area of square = side², so side = √area. Volume of cube = side³, so side = ∛volume.

keyTerms.definition: Number r such that r² = n; written √n.
Number r such that r³ = n; written ∛n.
Number that is the square of an integer (e.g., 9 = 3²).

nsbTraps: √(a² + b²) is not a + b. √9 = 3, not ±3, when we mean the principal (nonnegative) root.
didYouKnow: √2 is irrational—it cannot be written as a fraction of integers.

subject: Math
title: Algebraic Expressions & Equations
whatIsIt: An expression has numbers, variables, and operations (e.g., 3x + 2). An equation has an equals sign and can be solved for the variable.
howItWorks: Combine like terms (same variable and exponent). Use distributive property: a(b + c) = ab + ac. To solve an equation, do the same operation to both sides to isolate the variable. Check by substituting the solution back.
realWorldExample: If tickets cost $5 each plus $2 fee, total = 5n + 2. Solving 5n + 2 = 17 gives n = 3 tickets.

keyTerms.definition: Letter representing an unknown or changing quantity.
Terms with the same variable(s) and exponent(s); can be combined.
a(b + c) = ab + ac; multiply each term inside by the factor outside.

nsbTraps: 2x and x² are not like terms. When you multiply (x+2)(x+3), use distributive property (FOIL or area model).
didYouKnow: Algebra lets you solve problems without guessing—write an equation and solve.

subject: Math
title: Linear Equations & Inequalities
whatIsIt: A linear equation has variables to the first power (e.g., 2x + 3 = 7). Linear inequalities use <, >, ≤, ≥; solution is often a range.
howItWorks: Solve linear equations: isolate the variable using inverse operations (add, subtract, multiply, divide both sides). Inequalities: same steps, but if you multiply or divide by a negative, flip the inequality sign. Graph linear equations as lines; inequalities as half-planes.
realWorldExample: 2x + 1 = 9 → x = 4. 'Score at least 70' → s ≥ 70.

keyTerms.definition: Equation whose graph is a straight line; form ax + b = c or y = mx + b.
Statement using <, >, ≤, or ≥; solution is a set of values.
Operation that undoes another (e.g., add and subtract).

nsbTraps: When multiplying or dividing an inequality by a negative number, reverse the inequality sign.
didYouKnow: Linear equations have at most one solution; inequalities have infinitely many (a range).

subject: Math
title: Systems of Equations
whatIsIt: A system is two or more equations with the same variables. A solution satisfies all equations at once. For two linear equations in two unknowns, solution is where the lines intersect.
howItWorks: Methods: substitution (solve one equation for one variable, substitute into the other) or elimination (add/subtract equations to eliminate a variable). Number of solutions: one (lines cross), none (parallel), or infinitely many (same line).
realWorldExample: Two items total $10; one costs $3 more than the other—two equations, two unknowns.

keyTerms.definition: Set of equations with the same variables; solution satisfies all.
Solving for one variable and plugging into another equation.
Adding or subtracting equations to cancel a variable.

nsbTraps: Check your solution in both equations. Parallel lines mean no solution (inconsistent).
didYouKnow: Systems show up in supply and demand, mixture problems, and many real-world models.

subject: Math
title: Functions & Graphing
whatIsIt: A function assigns exactly one output to each input. It can be given by a rule (e.g., f(x) = 2x + 1), a table, or a graph. The graph of y = f(x) shows all (input, output) pairs.
howItWorks: Linear function: y = mx + b; m is slope, b is y-intercept. Slope = rise/run = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁). Graph by plotting points or using slope and intercept. Domain = possible inputs; range = possible outputs. Vertical line test: a graph is a function if no vertical line hits it more than once.
realWorldExample: Distance = rate × time is a linear function of time. A graph of speed vs. time shows how speed changes.

keyTerms.definition: Rule that assigns exactly one output to each input.
Rate of change; rise over run; m in y = mx + b.
Where the graph crosses the y-axis; value of y when x = 0; b in y = mx + b.

nsbTraps: Slope is change in y over change in x, not the other way around. Vertical lines have undefined slope.
didYouKnow: Not every equation in x and y is a function—e.g., x² + y² = 1 (circle) fails the vertical line test.

subject: Math
title: Geometry: Angles, Lines & Triangles
whatIsIt: Angles are measured in degrees. Lines can be parallel (never meet) or perpendicular (right angle). Triangles have three angles that sum to 180°; types by sides (scalene, isosceles, equilateral) or angles (acute, right, obtuse).
howItWorks: Complementary angles sum to 90°; supplementary to 180°. Vertical angles are equal. Parallel lines cut by a transversal give equal corresponding and alternate interior angles. Triangle sum: angle sum = 180°.
realWorldExample: A ladder against a wall forms a right triangle. Parallel railroad tracks and a crossing create congruent angles.

keyTerms.definition: Two angles whose sum is 90°.
Two angles whose sum is 180°.
Angles opposite each other when two lines cross; they are equal.

nsbTraps: In a triangle, the largest angle is opposite the longest side. Don't assume 'vertical' means 90°—vertical angles are across from each other.
didYouKnow: The angles of any triangle add up to exactly 180°—true for every triangle.

subject: Math
title: Geometry: Polygons & Area
whatIsIt: A polygon is a closed figure with straight sides. Area is the amount of space inside. Formulas: rectangle A = lw, triangle A = ½bh, parallelogram A = bh, trapezoid A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h.
howItWorks: Count sides for names: triangle (3), quadrilateral (4), pentagon (5), hexagon (6). Sum of interior angles of an n-gon = (n - 2)×180°. Area formulas depend on shape; height is perpendicular to the base.
realWorldExample: Floor area = length × width. A triangular banner has area ½ × base × height.

keyTerms.definition: Closed figure with straight sides.
Measure of the region inside a 2D figure; in square units.
Quadrilateral with two pairs of parallel sides; A = base × height.

nsbTraps: In a triangle, the 'height' must be perpendicular to the base—the side is not always the height.
didYouKnow: A square is a rectangle and a rhombus; a rectangle is a parallelogram.

subject: Math
title: Geometry: Circles
whatIsIt: A circle is all points equidistant from the center. Radius r is that distance; diameter d = 2r. Circumference C = 2πr = πd. Area A = πr².
howItWorks: Circumference is the perimeter of the circle. Area is π times radius squared (not diameter). An arc is part of the circumference; central angle (in degrees) gives arc length = (angle/360)×2πr. Sector area = (angle/360)×πr².
realWorldExample: Tire circumference determines how far the car goes per rotation. Pizza area = πr².

keyTerms.definition: Distance from center of circle to any point on the circle.
Perimeter of a circle; C = 2πr = πd.
Distance across the circle through the center; d = 2r.

nsbTraps: Area is πr²—if you're given diameter, use r = d/2 first. π is about 3.14 (or use the π key).
didYouKnow: π is irrational—its decimal never repeats and never ends.

subject: Math
title: Geometry: 3D Shapes
whatIsIt: Three-dimensional shapes have volume (space inside) and surface area (total area of all faces). Common shapes: prism, pyramid, cylinder, cone, sphere.
howItWorks: Prism (including cube, rectangular box): volume = base area × height; surface area = sum of areas of all faces. Cylinder: V = πr²h; SA = 2πr² + 2πrh. Sphere: V = (4/3)πr³; SA = 4πr². Cone: V = (1/3)πr²h.
realWorldExample: Volume of a box = length × width × height. Volume of a can = πr²h.

keyTerms.definition: Amount of space inside a 3D shape; in cubic units.
Total area of all faces (or curved surface) of a 3D shape.
3D shape with two parallel congruent bases and rectangular lateral faces.

nsbTraps: Cube has 6 faces; surface area = 6s². Don't confuse volume (cubic units) with surface area (square units).
didYouKnow: A sphere has the most volume for a given surface area—so bubbles are round.

subject: Math
title: The Pythagorean Theorem
whatIsIt: In a right triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the legs: a² + b² = c², where c is the hypotenuse (side opposite the right angle).
howItWorks: Only works for right triangles. Identify the hypotenuse (longest side, opposite the right angle). Substitute the two legs and hypotenuse into a² + b² = c². Solve for the unknown. To find a leg: a² = c² - b².
realWorldExample: A 3-4-5 triangle is right (3² + 4² = 9 + 16 = 25 = 5²). Ladder against a wall: ladder length is hypotenuse.

keyTerms.definition: Longest side of a right triangle; opposite the right angle.
Either of the two sides of a right triangle that form the right angle.
In a right triangle, a² + b² = c² where c is the hypotenuse.

nsbTraps: The hypotenuse must be c—the side opposite the right angle. If you get a² + b² < c², you might have swapped.
didYouKnow: There are infinitely many Pythagorean triples (integer sides), e.g., 5-12-13, 8-15-17.

subject: Math
title: Coordinate Geometry
whatIsIt: The coordinate plane has x- and y-axes. Points are (x, y). Distance between two points: use Pythagorean theorem. Midpoint: average of x-coordinates, average of y-coordinates.
howItWorks: Distance: d = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]. Midpoint: M = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2). Slope m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁). Lines: y = mx + b (slope-intercept); parallel lines have same slope; perpendicular slopes multiply to -1.
realWorldExample: Map coordinates; distance between two cities; midpoint of a segment.

keyTerms.definition: Plane with x-axis (horizontal) and y-axis (vertical); points (x, y).
Point halfway between two points; average of coordinates.
d = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]; from Pythagorean theorem.

nsbTraps: Order doesn't matter in distance formula (squared), but slope is (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁)—keep order consistent.
didYouKnow: The coordinate plane is also called the Cartesian plane after René Descartes.

subject: Math
title: Probability & Combinatorics
whatIsIt: Probability is the chance of an event: P(event) = number of favorable outcomes / total outcomes (when equally likely). Combinatorics counts arrangements: permutations (order matters) and combinations (order doesn't).
howItWorks: Probability between 0 and 1 (or 0% and 100%). P(not A) = 1 - P(A). For independent events: P(A and B) = P(A)×P(B). Permutations: n!/(n-k)! for choosing k from n in order. Combinations: n!/(k!(n-k)!) for choosing k from n (order doesn't matter).
realWorldExample: P(heads) = 1/2. Number of ways to choose 3 people from 5: C(5,3) = 10.

keyTerms.definition: Number from 0 to 1 (or 0% to 100%) giving likelihood of an event.
Arrangement of items where order matters.
Selection of items where order does not matter.

nsbTraps: With and without replacement change the total and favorable counts. 'At least one' = 1 - P(none).
didYouKnow: n! (n factorial) = n × (n-1) × … × 1; 0! = 1 by convention.

subject: Math
title: Statistics
whatIsIt: Statistics summarizes and analyzes data. Mean (average), median (middle), and mode (most frequent) are measures of center. Range and standard deviation measure spread.
howItWorks: Mean = sum of values / number of values. Median: order data; middle value (or average of two middles). Mode: value that appears most. Range = max - min. Outliers can skew the mean but not the median.
realWorldExample: Test scores: mean = class average; median = middle score; mode = most common score.

keyTerms.definition: Average; sum of values divided by count.
Middle value when data are ordered; not affected much by outliers.
Value that appears most frequently.
Difference between maximum and minimum values.

nsbTraps: Median is the middle position, not the middle value of the range. For even number of values, median is average of the two middle values.
didYouKnow: Mean, median, and mode are equal in a symmetric distribution.

subject: Math
title: Sequences & Patterns
whatIsIt: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers following a rule. Arithmetic: add the same number each time (common difference d). Geometric: multiply by the same number (common ratio r).
howItWorks: Arithmetic: nth term aₙ = a₁ + (n - 1)d. Sum of n terms: S = n/2 × (first + last) or S = n/2 × (2a₁ + (n-1)d). Geometric: aₙ = a₁ × rⁿ⁻¹. Finding the rule: look at differences (arithmetic) or ratios (geometric).
realWorldExample: 2, 5, 8, 11, … is arithmetic (d = 3). 2, 6, 18, 54, … is geometric (r = 3).

keyTerms.definition: Sequence where the same number is added each time; linear pattern.
Sequence where the same number is multiplied each time; exponential pattern.
In arithmetic sequence, the number added each time (d).

nsbTraps: First term is n = 1, so aₙ = a₁ + (n-1)d, not a₁ + nd. Check the first few terms to see the pattern.
didYouKnow: The Fibonacci sequence (1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, …) is neither arithmetic nor geometric—each term is the sum of the two before.

subject: Math
title: Word Problems & Unit Conversions
whatIsIt: Word problems describe a situation in words; you translate to equations and solve. Unit conversions change from one unit to another using conversion factors (e.g., 1 ft = 12 in).
howItWorks: Read carefully; identify what is unknown (variable). Write an equation from the words. Solve. Check. Unit conversions: multiply by fractions equal to 1 (e.g., 12 in / 1 ft) so units cancel. Dimensional analysis: keep track of units to catch errors.
realWorldExample: If 3 pens cost $6, how much for 5 pens? (Proportion.) Convert 5 km to miles (5 × 0.621 ≈ 3.1 mi).

keyTerms.definition: Ratio of two equivalent quantities (e.g., 1 km = 1000 m) used to convert units.
Keeping track of units in calculations to ensure the answer has the right units.

nsbTraps: In conversions, set up so the unit you want stays and the one you don't want cancels. Rate problems: distance = rate × time.
didYouKnow: The metric system uses powers of 10—easier for conversions (1 km = 1000 m, 1 m = 100 cm).

subject: Physical Science
title: Scientific Method & Experimentation
whatIsIt: The scientific method is a process for answering questions: observe, ask a question, form a hypothesis, design an experiment, collect data, analyze, and draw conclusions. Experiments should be fair (control variables, one independent variable).
howItWorks: Hypothesis is a testable prediction. Independent variable is what you change; dependent variable is what you measure. Control group is used for comparison. Constants are kept the same. Repeat trials to improve reliability.
realWorldExample: Testing whether plants grow better with fertilizer: same light and water (constants), fertilizer vs no fertilizer (independent variable), plant height (dependent variable).

keyTerms.definition: Testable prediction or explanation for an observation.
Variable the experimenter changes.
Variable that is measured; may depend on the independent variable.
Group used for comparison; does not receive the treatment.

nsbTraps: Correlation does not prove causation. Only one independent variable should change per experiment.
didYouKnow: Scientists publish results so others can replicate experiments and verify findings.

subject: Math
title: Data & Graphs
whatIsIt: Data can be displayed in tables, bar graphs, line graphs, pie charts, and scatter plots. Choosing the right graph depends on the type of data and what you want to show.
howItWorks: Bar graphs: compare categories. Line graphs: show change over time. Pie charts: show parts of a whole. Scatter plots: show relationship between two variables. Always label axes and include a title.
realWorldExample: Temperature over a week → line graph. Favorite sports → bar or pie. Height vs weight → scatter plot.

keyTerms.definition: Graph that uses bars to compare categories.
Graph that shows how data change over time; points connected by lines.
Graph of points showing the relationship between two variables.

nsbTraps: Scale on axes can make differences look bigger or smaller—check the numbers.
didYouKnow: Misleading graphs often use a truncated scale or wrong scale to exaggerate effects.
